n1av7EZp7qdznuZyAdJHNA.text: Having afternoon tea was a MUST on our visit to London so we decided to tour Kensington Palace and have tea afterwards. The tour was just "meh" but the staff at the Orangery made us feel like royalty. We arrived a bit early since we didn't realize that tea doesnt begin until 2:00pm but our waiter allowed us to wait until two instead of ordering a lunch we didn't want. The tea was delicious as were the delectables that were served alongside the tea. Simply lovely afternoon!

XwkAVHCQrQJBfrM-neyf8g.text: This is a must when in London.  Everything was delicious.  We had cream cheese and cucumber sandwiches, scones with clotted cream, and cake.  Even the tea was excellent.The prices were reasonable.  The decor was very elegant (of course, you're at the orangery of Kensington Palace!).

FMVOoOncXcvBP318tVYMfA.text: For tea, there is no better place than Orangery. The Orangery is located inside the Kensington Palace grounds. The decor is lovely, sunlight streams through the tall windows and the view of the lush green gardens is delightful.  There are no reservations necessary. However at peak times, you can expect to wait 10-15 minutes to get seated.Prices are remarkably low. For £15, you get finger sandwiches, scone with butter and jam, and pastries. You also get you selection of tea, of which I highly recommend their Orange tea called Roobio (I think). We even shared a slice of the Orangery cake, which was is unique to Orangery and delightful to our taste buds.So why do I give it just 4 stars? Well, the service was average. For example, we asked for no ham in our sandwiches, so instead of asking us which  sandwich we wanted to replace it with, the waitress brought us more salmon dill sandwiches, when we would have preferred cucumber sandwiches.The toilets are outside to the back of the building and while clean, are inconvenient. Other than that, a great experience. For the price, there is none better.

igJsn2Ww1df4fGPi8xHogw.text: Good and affordable place to get afternoon tea.  Service was great and portions were more than fair.

bnl7pmYr8e-XxyKvC9l_Ig.text: In my opinion this place is quite overestimated. Although the environment is great and the cakes are delicious there were a couple of things I disliked.- the afternoon tea was way too expensive for what it was offering. - the food was well presented but didn't taste nearly as good - long queue so I had to wait for 20 minutes- the staff is not nearly pleasant as polite as they should be

vPklxi1hTh5V-Qn7ds1wRA.text: Afternoon tea experience:Good things first: nice terrace for a sunny day, nice interior too, reasonable pricing at around £20 per person (especially if you compare to the £50 in the fancy hotels!!)But that's all.Tea was... just teaSandwiches were okPastries were awful (tasteless, dry... why bother getting the calories without the pleasure?! my friend and I just left them...)The presentation trays and teacups were not very elegant - disappointing if you want the real lady-like afternoon tea experience - which is what we were looking for this close to the Kensington Palace. Very disappointed.

VtfAIxkb_80RP5jGLLV6eA.text: Fancy. Pants. But sometimes you need to put on a pair of pants that are fancy. And when you put them on, you should go to the Orangery at Kensington Palace. While it is a regular restaurant with a full menu, you really just need to go have afternoon tea. The ladyfriend and I opted for the Champagne Tea. We each received a pot of tea (the Ceylon was above reproach), four finger sandwiches, a scone with jam and clotted cream, two torts and a flute of champagne. The sandwiches are where the Orangery loses its star - my companion and I are both vegetarian, and one of the sandwiches was ham, and we could not substitute it for one of the other options. Apart from that, everything was perfect. The service was just a tad slow, but friendly, professional and worthy of no real complaints. The food was all to die for, and really, isn't good food why we are all here?When it comes to places like The Orangery, one is paying for the atmosphere. Personally, I think that this establishment is one of the more beautiful places that I have ever eaten - ornate and lovely, but not overdone or pretentious. The bright and airy hall, with a lovely view of the lawn and gardens, make for a wonderfully pleasing afternoon treat. The fact that the Champagne Tea was £21 per person, plus automatic service charge means that I will not be going back as often as I would like, but I do plan on going back as much as my grad-student budget will allow.

viFHalt5zwWMJvvxegcsQg.text: My mom and I decided to come here partly as a good excuse to walk through the park and gardens. We had breakfast and by the time we finished strolling through, we were freezing. We walked in and grabbed a table by the window. My mom had tea and a danish, I had the full English breakfast and orange juice. Everything tasted great. The prices were quite reasonable. Service was prompt and helpful. Would love to come back for afternoon tea next time.

Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

UA7mhzIxM4f-7Idd0ou7kw.text: I haven't been in London long enough to say that this is the best place for afternoon tea/lunch since I don't have anything to compare it to. I was really excited to finally get the real deal (I've had afternoon tea at a British tea room in the US) and this place didn't let me down. There was a line to get seated, but the service wasn't bad considering how many tables they were serving inside and outside on the patio. The interior was nice; spacious, high ceilings, statues at both ends of the building...it was beautiful with the sun shining through the high windows.I ordered the Signature Orange Tea, which came with an assortment of finger sandwiches, a scone, chocolate eclair, and an orange and passion fruit tart; I decided to go with the recommended rooibos breakfast tea.Our teas came out first; mine was a loose leaf tea, so I was given a strainer (I've never had loose leaf tea before...). The rooibos breakfast tea smelled amazing and tasted amazing. I didn't put any sugar or cream in it because the flavor was enough for me. I wish I could have bought some of the tea to take home!The finger sandwiches were fresh and delicious. I really enjoyed the scone with clotted cream and jam; it had a hint of orange flavor to it too. The fruit tart was unlike anything I've tasted before; it wasn't too sweet and it was a perfect blend of flavors. The chocolate éclair wasn't too great, but that was only one item out of the entire selection. I was rather full after eating the sandwiches and scone, but managed to finish off the tart because it was so good. All of this for ~16 pounds (including service charge); this was the best 16 pounds I've spent on food and drinks! If I get a chance, I'd like to come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. we waited in line and there was still a line when we left
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. rooibos breakfast tea (loose leaf)
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

dlgaw_z-VGFOhto6oGpK9w.text: On my birthday I decided I wanted to spent the day with my hubs and visit Kensington Palace and go to The Orangery afterward. We came up to the entrance and was blown away at how bright and warm it looked inside. Beautiful venue.We stood and waited to be seated. One server looks at us, looks away. Another server looks at us, looks away. Another server looks at us, looks away. Finally someone felt sorry for us and seated us.We ordered an afternoon tea that came with chocolate cakes. I substituted my tea with a coffee. When the drinks finally came my coffee was lukewarm. So disappointed. That dampened my mood even more. Not even the delicious orange scone cheered me up. Nothing makes me more upset than being ignored by servers and getting a lukewarm coffee and for both to happen at the same place made for a very sad Mela.When we got our bill we were given a comment card to fill out. You better believe I filled it out and personally handed it to the manager upon exiting. Don't keep me waiting *and* mess with my coffee.

tey1YoBib-K3dk_g4dgqCw.text: Classy and yet you could dress down with relaxing garden ambiance. Delish dark choco, pastries and variety mini slice of sandwich. Your paying for the royal place not the portion of the food your eating. Lovely last day Afternoon Tea experience!

j0atjL3V7N-wrs8JCKvhUQ.text: The setting is gorgeous, but it does not make up for the lacklustre meal served. I ordered the afternoon tea that included tea sandwiches, scone, pastries and the suggested orange tea. Unfortunately, the sandwich bread and scone tasted like it had been sitting out since yesterday - hardly fresh and stale tasting.I was so looking forward to eating here amid all the wonderful reviews, but I could have eaten a better sandwich and scone which was plain by the way sans sultanas at Marks & Spencers.On the bright side, the pastries were decent and the tea was excellent. The table and dishware were very well presented. Service was a bit slow, but the waitstaff was pleasant enough.I would give the food a 1.5-star rating but gave it a 2 because of the beautiful scenery. I elected to sit outdoors overlooking the gardens.

Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea tier

4hQGhblsuyGgZlRaqc8g-g.text: Afternoon tea is a must at The Orangery on the grounds of Kensington Palance. I was in search of a moderately-priced afternoon tea service and discovered this gem. The cost is only £13.65 per person compared to two or three times as much for afternoon tea at hotels. It's not a typical tea service in that you get a tiered dessert tray. The spread of savory snacks and petit fours is set up on a table in the middle of the cafe (yelp.com/user_local_phot…). Sometimes that setup is better because if you like one or two treats a lot, it's basically AYCE. The space is elegant and relaxing (yelp.com/user_local_phot…). I could easily spend hours there sipping tea and snacking.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon Tea

YccXubLZ5CBg3nfdPaOlKQ.text: I've been to the Orangery twice, once for tea and once for pudding, and both times were delicious! The weather was perfect when I went for tea, allowing us to sit outside in the sun basking over our cream tea. The next time, we were a larger group and sat inside. We had barely missed tea time, but insisted on getting pudding. I got the chocolate chip bread and butter pudding. It was amazing! Soft and not too overpowering. While it is a bit pricey, I love coming here. It's a London must-do!

dGZVrtgG2ICo0sO7pNxiTg.text: So, in fairness, should you dock a star or two for the lackluster service of a Serbian waiter at a traditional british tea service?  Well, if you have been to London recently, you probably have noticed that NONE of your servers are Brits, so I am going to give a resounding yes.Took the children to experience British Tea at the lovely Orangery at Kensington Palace.  I have had tea there before so I knew the atmosphere was delightful but not too stuffy for children.  Indeed they offer a children's tea, though I believe most places do now.  At 2:30 on a gorgeous summer day, we waited 30 minutes in line for a table (The Orangery does not take reservations; note to self, Go somewhere which does).  There were definitely open tables available but the staff was not efficient in changing over the linens and dishes and so we waited.  Fortunately, our 6 and 9 year olds could romp around the grounds while we stood in line.When we were finally seated, our very S-L-O-W waiter took his time ambling over to us.  And we waited, and waited, and waited for our order.  Our delicacies came at least 10-15 minutes before our tea; why?  Were the dishwashers slow?  Was the hot tap turned off?Before we had consumed all of our treats, my husband and I ordered a second glass of champagne, from someone whom I had assumed was the manager after I had tried vainly to flag down our server.And then we waited, and waited, and waited.... we ended up ordering the champagne a second time from yet another server and asked him to also bring the tab, immediately.I do enjoy a leisurely tea, when I actually have what I have ordered in front of me.  Also, I was beginning to feel a bit sheepish, sitting at my table for an hour and 45 minutes whilst the line continued to grow and other would-be patrons began staring at us.For the money, which is not a pittance, I would suggest going someplace, perhaps any place, else.  London has no dearth of fine establishments which serve tea.

J3hd_9Ul16HogZ_O9nkMgA.text: Visitor from New York City. Took my mom to have our first tea here!Affordable and filling! When you walk in you are greeted by a table pilled high with a spread of scones and cakes. Didn't mind leering at it while we waited for a table. Gorgeous white room and there's a palace outside, man. THE FOOD:Great tea (we had Darjeeling with Orange oil, in keeping with the room theme). Loved the strawberry Victoria special cake. Scones good. Not big fan of the cucumber sandwiches though. Service a bit frazzled but I didn't mind it too much.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. cream cheese & cucumber sandwiches

8JsXuSG7SBF_8FA97CQ3Pg.text: I was a little disappointed with my afternoon tea experience at the Orangery. First, just a warning that the place is a little hard to find. Second, when we got there, even though we made a reservation, nothing seemed to be set up for us. When the tea pots and cups came out, some of then were dirty so we had to ask them to replace our set. The sandwiches were bland and the cakes were tiny and average-tasting. Best part was the scones, but I think I liked the ones at Bea's if Bloomsbury better. Bea's was cheaper, too; Orangery came out to be 32 pounds per person which is almost 50 dollars...I really didn't feel like it was worth that kind of money.

-I3zIIHfbV4F6vP-TI2APw.text: I had the Afternoon Champagne Tea yesterday at the Orangery and it was a pleasent experience.  A few things:1) They don't take reservations...expect to wait outside.  If the weather is nice,  it is okay as it is in a beautiful area.2)  The tea is nice and the food is good as well.  I have to be honest and say that I did afternoon tea at The Charlotte Street hotel and, while the ambience is better at The Orangery....the tea and food was better at C. Street.3)  Just a request...don't bring crying kids here.  If you have kids,  that is wonderful.  If they get upset,  please take them outside.  We had a baby yelling through about 60% of our time there.  4)  Walk the gardens after...they are beautiful!It wasn't the best tea I have ever been to but I recommend it if you have guests in town...just for the experience.

BAzE5k8Hk08U_gjJrkHIKw.text: As far as settings go for a real English afternoon tea, it doesn't really get much better than a palace in Kensington Garden, across the street from Princess Diana's home.  I was told The Orangery was a posh place to go for tea, and it certainly was!  Bright white walls are accented with tall, dramatic windows to let patrons soak in every ounce of the surrounding garden and the occasional ray of British sunshine.  You're greeted with pastries arranged like performers are tiered in an Orchestra--the cakes and scones seem to dance for you upon your arrival, seducing you to buy one immediately.The service was medicore... but I guess that's not surprising when most of the tip is included on this side of the pond--whether you like it or not.  The English-grown Tragothnan Green tea was a tea-lovers pot of heaven.  The food was not really impressive in and of itself--the eclair, orange scented scone, and finger sandwiches were pretty run-of-the-mill in my humble opinion.  What you cannot miss is the amazing Orangery cake which is buttery, sugary, slightly citrus, and the absolute perfect accompaniment to the tea.  It's worth its weight in gold... or here, the 5 pound price tag.  What I liked best about The Orangery was that I got to have my posh afternoon tea experience in a gorgeous setting for about 15 pounds after all was said and done, significantly less than the 50 pounds they ask for afternoon tea at Harrods.

3O057SWn6pyjvpYoMkGHjA.text: It's attached to Kensington Palace, and it's a perfect location for tea if you're a tourist. Afternoon tea purists might recoil in horror, but my verdict? Not bad. This was my second time since early 2008 - end of May 2011, and NOTHING has changed. Hey, if it ain't broke. The sandwiches are bland and cold, the desserts - a chocolate torte thing which was kind of dry, and a rather tasty peach tart - could use some improvement. The standout was the scone with raisins - so satisfying and moist and dense at the same time, with lovely clotted cream and fruit preserves (which may come from a jar), but I'm not complaining. I had the chocolate tea which was exceptional - a light and pleasant tea with notes of cocoa. Yum. I was intrigued to see how they would pull off chocolate tea, and they nailed it. My one regret - I didn't get the raspberry meringue - they looked like miniature clouds you'd eat in heaven.The decor is light and bright, looks like a Greek palace, and the staff is as bland as the sandwiches. But you're there for the experience, and it was certainly a good one.

hi4n2NCijZLJEabUAlh25A.text: Talk about have tea in London! This place is a must! Not only do you get to have to in Kensington Gardens surrounded by some of the most beautiful gardens but then you walk into this picture perfect all white tea room. The only thing we regret is not sitting outside and enjoying the view, but it was a bit chilly. The tea was great, but I am a huge tea drinker so I recommend the lemon and ginger tea, it suits my pallet. The mini sandwiches were good too! My husband fell in love with the biscuits

bMZrF4tYigQgi1EwJ17QXg.text: Great place to take a friend for a birthday afternoon tea. We had the champagne afternoon tea and thoroughly enjoyed it.We were seated in the room at the very end on the left, with a prime view of the gardens outside. I think it was because there were three of us, but even though we got there 20 minutes before the couples seated by us, our food took ages to come. Oh well, I guess you come for the setting and the grandeur of having afternoon tea and not necessarily a punctual service!

635hxTZ7Hdu1DYPXUIx89w.text: For a classic afternoon tea time, definitely come here! Love the atmosphere of the place!

5Wu2GokcSLPNAPYCWISG0g.text: Went to afternoon tea, and it was amazing! About 20 different types of tea to choose from. Everything on the tower that came with the tea was amazing. Our reservation was at 12 pm when The Orangery opened. The waiter was so nice and let us pick any table we wanted. We asked for a table by a window that seated more then the amount of people we had in our party but he was happy to oblige. He was so nice and even opened the window to let the beautiful afternoon blow in.

YIjsO2Xv9eJCkZjLtVS-ZA.text: Such beauty, simplicity, and comfort,In cup and plate.In green, lush gardens.Lovely, nurturing, indulgence.Thank you.

FnAB_axu0CyfByrAFCBAMA.text: Not only is The Orangery a beautiful venue for afternoon tea, but Kensington Gardens is a fantastic backdrop! What an experience to walk the gardens and see how lucky the English are to have such a wonderful area to escape the hustle and bustle of city life. The Orangery has massive windows that allows for natural lighting. The high quality of tea service is outstanding. Simply sitting and sipping tea at the Orangery makes one feel like royalty. If you are looking for top-notch afternoon tea in a gorgeous setting, then go to the Orangery. I highly recommend making advanced reservations, as there is a long line and wait for drop-ins.

whBgCIFQBIzWygdEedlwkg.text: Anticlimatic. Great View and location but the food fell short for me. Considering how much it was and the fact that I was in London, I was expecting better. Again, call me spoiled but I've been to several high tea places in California and it pretty much was at a similar caliber and cheaper in the states..... eeks. Bathroom is far from the dining area so that was annoying.

skaslvsUUgOFdf18pwxD5Q.text: This place is special.  The food and service are probably 3.5 stars but the location more than makes up for it.  It is right next to Kensington Palace, in the park.  Enough to make all your Jane Austen, Royals, Anglophile dreams come true.  I had a croissant with ham and cheese and my bf had the Full English Breakfast.  We got there early so there was no wait, but as the day went on it got more crowded.  We sat outside with the tremendous view, but the inside looked beautiful as well.  A must see.

MRXCLgTLtfbNo357HtypfQ.text: Situated right next to Kensington Palace, The Orangery is an ideal location for the full British experience of afternoon tea without breaking your wallet. Although it is definitely less traditional, the setting is beautiful and complements the porcelain silverware and tea settings. The basic afternoon tea is 24 pounds per person, and you get a filling amount of sandwiches, scones, and desserts. It includes an array of sandwiches, from cucumber mint to smoked salmon and cream cheese. These were average in my opinion, but it was a good break from the sweeter options on the stand. The scones, both the plain and the orange raisin, were buttery and soft, but I would have liked it better if they were served warmer! The selection of desserts was amazing, from fruit tarts to marzipan cake to chocolate raspberry cake. The size of each was just small enough to make you feel only slightly guilty if you wanted to sample and finish them all! The assortment of teas was also great, but make sure you indicate to the waiter if you want to substitute the type of tea included in your set, otherwise they will serve a default English tea. I tried the wild berry infused tea, which was very fragrant and naturally sweetened with both apples and berries. Regardless, any tea you choose will be served in a beautiful pot and provide the perfect counterbalance to the sweet treats. Afternoon tea is a necessity when visiting London, but The Orangery is a great place to get the best bang for your buck. Other teas can get extremely expensive, so if you're looking for just a basic experience with delicious food, then this is the place to go!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for two

0HlcjazI76DWj3GYnudQGw.text: Came here for afternoon tea at 4 pm. It was not that busy besides my reservation, probably due to the low season in February. The price per person starts at £30. I had traditional English breakfast tea, which came with variety of pastries and sandwiches. However, I was not impressed. Food was OK, some pastries were dry (maybe old). The atmosphere is really nice though.

Y8ZF2OhqjWZgBCabSxiFpA.text: I agree with some of the previous reviews that the price for tea here is overpriced. However, I guess you are paying to have tea at a palace. The Orangery is nice, but the real reason why you should visit is the beautiful Kensington Gardens. The tea was ok, but not great. The service was acceptable. All in all, it was a fun experience to have while in London.Definitely make a reservation because the line without is a little ridiculous (I was able to make a reservation on their website).

8IhlfdOCJX5XxaXBXdpHuA.text: I'm in love with the Orangery!On the first day coming here the Orangery just closed for a private party and the guy in the front refused to let us in. I was sooo bummed out.But we came the next day and got seated after a brief wait.I ended up ordering their famous orange afternoon high tea set.I'm a huge tea junkie... :) it was everything I could have imagined... sipping afternoon high tea in London on my birthday!I got a lot of great photos and if I'm ever back in London I would love to come here again! But yes... it's really expensive!Cheers!-Miss Yelp 2012

z4a6SPlbp92lqsBQdRyBww.text: A review for afternoon tea...One of my dearest, and most longstanding friends came for a visit to London -- and being that her name is Aynsley (English china, I believe) and that she enjoys the finer things in life (as do I), I saw it fitting to find a place for us to enjoy a traditional afternoon tea. My first ever in London as well! Wanting to avoid the hotel scene, and also to include some sightseeing --- The Orangery was the perfect locale, situated pristinely on the grounds of Kensington Palace, near Hyde Park and the beautiful Kensington Gardens. Of course, it was raining so there was no patio perching for our pair, but we were delighted in the experience nonetheless. We had a 1:30pm reservation (the latest I could get) -- without realizing that afternoon tea service does not start until 2pm. Consequently, there was a que at 1:50pm, that snaked around the front of the building. We found ourselves rather lucky to be enjoying a crisp glass of champagne whilst awaiting the 2 o'clock hour to begin tea. I believe this to be a lucky circumstance with a nice waiter, and also the promise that we would be ordering the most expensive tea service on the menu (32/pp). Quite pricey, and worth his service and patience and table...though I'm not sure if this would work again, I might try it anyway. Protip: splurge on the nice champagne with the highest tea service. One only lives once and how often do you take out of towners for tea? Not often. If you are here, you are likely either visiting or with someone visiting, so make it special. That glass is worth it. The actual tea itself was quite nice, with the three-tiered offering of finger sandwiches, pastries, jams, scones, clotted creams and petit cookies. We were offered refreshes on our teas often and without hesitation. We were encouraged to linger, despite the que -- but wrapped up our affair by 3pm and were on our way...stopping at the gardens for a quick peek around, gawking at the palace at bit, and then making our way for a walk in Hyde Park. Add it to your "tourist" list -- and enjoy that champagne. *There is also a back room to host private parties. On this particular day it was a child's birthday party. Fancy! *The toilets are around the side of the building, you'll need a code from the staff to enter.

6QaWyXrCKiFgxbWKBd4Lig.text: Wonderful afternoon tea at The Orangery! Kensington Palace was lovely on a sunny afternoon, and the Royal Afternoon Tea menu with a glass of Pimm's were exactly what you want on such a day. Really nice experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea, The Orangery
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea, The Orangery

aJCFBopkbRnRXCJQZ8hV8w.text: I came here on a Monday for afternoon tea, and it was absolutely delightful!Three of my friends were visiting from the States and I wanted to do the most touristy things imaginable with them. Hello, antiquated midday tradition! I liked the idea of coming to The Orangery because the walk through perfectly manicured Kensington Park is gorgeous and provided several impromptu photo shoot opportunities. Anyways, I made a reservation the day before, so we were seated as soon as we arrived. Our hostess was pleasant and helped us sort through the variety of teas. We each ended up ordering a pot of the lady grey and it was easily the best tea I've ever had (and this is coming from someone from a long line of serious tea drinkers!). I also enjoyed the scones, chocolate, and other desserts. I can't say that I was a huge fan of finger sandwiches, but my distaste has more to do with personal preference than food quality. Besides the food and tea, the aesthetic of the building and presentation is exquisite. The building features a classic white, elegant decor and grand lofted ceilings. The china pattern on the teacups and saucers is gilded with splashes of turquoise and a rosy floral print. This setting creates a beautiful backdrop for a lovely spot of tea. I would highly recommend this to any tourist, or a Londoner who just feels like being fancy.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Menu.
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for two!
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Fancy snack time :D

lyQzgzL-85blzkMdTkUhMQ.text: First of all, go for breakfast and order the waffle with cinnamon cream and peaches. Second, we had the best experience. I left my phone in a cab before coming in and I was visiting from America and freaking out. So we told the hostess and she let us use her phone to call. Then we told the waiter and he left us with his phone and said call as many times as we want. Eventually someone answered and we got it back. The staff was so helpful and it was amazing. They went above and beyond to help us when they didn't have to do anything. Foods yummy, atmosphere is cute as heck and super British looking. The staff is amazing. So just go. It's a must whenever I go to London now.

ctgNyoCfLS5aPfysIU0MUw.text: Went to Orangery to celebrate my mother's birthday so she could have a English High Tea experience. This was perfect, set in the Kensington Palace ground the building with its high ceiling and tall windows gave the room a sense of grandeur. We had the Royal High tea with Pimms cocktail. The savoury plate of wraps and sandwiches was delicious, loved the mint in the cucumber sandwiches. Had the BEST SCONES with yummy strawberry jam and cream. Only negative was the last plate of cakes and pastries tray was a bit dry and they brought the hot drinks when we still had 3/4 of our cocktail left so they went cold. My mum really enjoyed that you could substitute the tea with a hot chocolate. She also loved the little happy birthday plate :). Defiantly will bring all my friends and family when they come to visit.

-08DLeSsCXVLecNsYgmg4A.text: Holy crap, I'm in London and having tea in the gardens of an English Palace. CHECK! Please excuse my overly excited American self as I am just so excited by this place!First off, the location is GREAT. It's in the garden, converted greenhouse of Kensington Palace with a gorgeous ambiance and view of the grounds. Now I can say I've had tea where Queen Anne used to. This place comes with fancy table linens, palace place settings (costs a pretty penny, trust me I know), and waitstaff in their full livery. Add in the garden statues, plants, and all white decor, you feel downright fancy in this place. If I didn't think I would insult any Brits I would've tried to speak with a posh accent the entire time I was there...Now the the important part. Food and Drink. I may have been distracted by the gorgeous, fancy settings, but I thought the tea and food was great! To me a lot of afternoon teas (especially in the states) are too sweet, creamy, salty, and heavy. Afternoon tea in my mind is supposed to be a light and airy snacktime between lunch and late dinner. The boyfriend and I got the Afternoon Tea set that included Egg mayonnaise and cress bridge roll (soft, light and perfect), smoked salmon and cream cheese mini bagel (perfectly creamy), Coronation chicken wrap (DELISH!), cucumber and fresh mint sandwich (refreshing) and Orange-scented and currant scones served with Cornish clotted cream, English strawberry jam (TO DIE FOR!!!!!) and an assortment of tea pastries. I've unfortunately forgotten what the tea pastries were because I was kind of in a happy daze. Either way, the boyfriend and I were quite happy with our food. And he's pretty picky since he doesn't love tea and is weirded out by a supposedly "female" activity. They had a wide variety of teas and I ended up with the Palace's version of the Lady Grey tea: Earl Grey Blue Flowers.Pricing wise, I have paid way more and felt less fancy in places like the Ritz, where yes I got more food. But I don't go to tea to be over fed and over sugared. This, in my mind, is the iconic, classic image of royal afternoon tea that I have read about in books.Overall, I could not find a single thing wrong with the place.

sXOv4urjE9qRl2Os2h2SGQ.text: After the wife and I left the Orangery, we realized that the novelty of the place isn't so much the afternoon tea or the service, but the setting. On a summer day, we were sure that the Orangery would be a brilliant place to have tea.But since it wasn't, the food and the service had to carry the day. And it didn't really. The tea was fine, but the scones were only so-so, the sweets and pastries tasted like leftovers, the finger sandwiches (except for the salmon) were bland. The service was also a bit lacking- everyone seemed like they were counting down until the end of their shift, except for one waiter who was cheery and very competent. Gents, if you want to impress your (American) girlfriends, keep an eye on the weather before you come here. If the sun is shining, you'll have a great time. Otherwise, I would pass on the Orangery.

yTdSsebUikYk5BWFxUifiA.text: What a beautiful setting to have afternoon tea, in middle of Kensington garden, looking out into the rose garden, green lawn with choice of indoor or outdoor seating.  I felt like royalty, and really can get used to this afternoon tea thing.  The English really know how to enjoy themselves and thank goodness we have the opportunity to experience their afternoon tea habit.  The food itself was very yummy, finger food of sandwiches, scones and cakes.  It cost 26 pounds per set, 35 pounds if you want champagne to go with your tea, fairly price compared to other tea places.  I think for this price and venue this is as good as the afternoon tea experience gets! Thumbs up!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea set #1, (26 pounds)

HR8baJ5lDNKjakKeUakAdA.text: Dear Orangery, your tea service is spectacular. I will be back. Sincerely, Natalie.Ok, I do want to write more than that, but seriously if you're looking for a place to have a nice tea, LOOK NO FURTHER! I've had the tea service at Harrod's and while that was a great experience, I have to say I liked tea at the Orangery even better. I went with a group of colleagues while on a business trip to London. We made a reservation, which I would highly recommend. They may be able to fit you in as a walk-in with a small party, but reservations help. I was impressed by the selection of tea and tisane on their menu. I generally cannot do caffeine, and usually resign myself to a decaf earl grey that most places have. The orangery had several herbal choices (completely caffeine free). Each person receives their own pot of tea, which catered to my selfish American ways ;)We had the traditional afternoon service, and for each pair at the table we received a platter of goodies. Raisin scones with jam and clotted cream were probably my favorite. This was my first experience with clotted cream, and and must say the English have a winner on their hands! It's a delicious spread that is basically thick, slightly sweetened cream. I could feel it going straight to my thighs...and I loved it. Several little cakes and pastries I couldn't quite identify, but all were delicious. The cucumber sandwiches were a refreshing choice on a warm afternoon, and though I loved the sweets, provided a nice contrast.The place settings were lovely. Bright aqua and pink colors. There is a story about the orangery's history on the back of the menu, which is informative and interesting. Something neat to read while waiting for the rest of your party to arrive. The location is very idyllic. You must walk through Hyde Park to get there, and have the opportunity to pass Kensington Palace as well. There is a pond nearby, and as you walk up to the Orangery take note of the elegantly pruned trees and lush greenery. A few minutes here, and you begin to feel like royalty yourself!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

fS8jTbnJQLefVwXHN0Zr3w.text: Stunning location (interior and exterior) and a great opportunity to say you had high tea in London. Seriously, I gasped when I saw the building and then when I walked inside. Gorgeous! Location 5/5Ambiance 5/5Service 4/5Food 4/5 (5/5 for tea and sandwiches, 3/5 for scones, 2/5 for dessert)It's a less expensive tea than you'd get in other places in there city, but it's a bit pricey to what I've paid in other cities. I would have been happier to pay the 30 pounds (roughly $55) if it had been all outstanding, but only certain parts of the actual food were primo in my book. The tea itself: perfection. You get your own little pot and out renders around 4 cups, which is standard. The sandwiches were fantastic and easily the best part of the meal other than the tea itself. The scones (one plain and one raisin) were okay, the jam and clotted cream were also okay. The dessert, what I was looking forward to most, was not good. I didn't eat two out of the four mini deserts. They lacked flavor for my palate, but maybe it's just me. The food was all very pretty. Would I do it again? Yeah, I would. It's a pretty place. I might order lunch instead of high tea next time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The presentation is quite lovely
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Dessert was prettier than it tasted.. But so pretty
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

zXHhE48oDnJ0ZQcigPc1Ig.text: We made reservations for afternoon tea, and luckily we did because there was a line out the door by the time we left. The interior is elegant and bright with floor to ceiling windows. There were a number of families and tourists, but they did not at all take away from the experience. The tables are simply but beautifully decorated, and our server was welcoming and attentive. Three of us had the English Afternoon Tea, and the other two had the pork belly and seared tuna.The Lady Grey was delicious (a floral Earl Grey), although the sandwiches and desserts were just good (not fantastic, but not bad either). The pork belly was again okay, but the seared tuna was disappointing. In general, I expect tuna to be seared rare, but this one was cooked through and on the dry side.Nevertheless, we really enjoyed our lunch at the Orangery. From the classy environment to the wonderful service, I would definitely recommend afternoon tea at the Orangery.ATMOSPHERE: 5/5SERVICE: 5/5FOOD: 3.5/5VALUE: 3.5/5OVERALL: 4/5

1MmVTpcpDEdrCyIZFhqdCw.text: After touring Kensington Palace, my friends and opted for an afternoon tea. It was so nice and the atmosphere was magical. I enjoyed my Earl Grey tea and the refreshments that were served. Can't wait to return for more tea at the Orangery!

9gJspgqn8VF15A91zuR4Qw.text: Disappointing. Do not go here for tea if you're hungry. The tea sandwiches taste of stale bread and were so tiny it almost seemed like a joke. The scones were good as well as the desserts, but not worth the £30 I paid.On a good note, the staff was lovely And the ambiance is quite nice! Maybe I'd come back for breakfast or lunch based in others photos but not for tea!

ujrIcfJM2KMG_R6_saW3Qw.text: Total disappointment. We were so excited to have high tea here and let's just say we have had it in many places in London and worldwide. The room is beautiful. It ends there. Lame crass food. The mediocre sandwiches terrible pasteries and barely okay scones. Careless service. We kept looking for the waiter. I'm embarrassed for them and left feeling ripped off. Stay away. They're are so many better choices in London. Do some research.

dKcMGR0KVjvlrtmalItimQ.text: Afternoon tea in the Kensington Gardens on a lovely Saturday afternoon - does life get better than this? The prices are fairly reasonable too especially considering the location. Reservations are easy to make on opentable, and the menu is straightforward. I loved the maracon with the pastry basket, and they make it easy for two to share a set.If tea isn't your thing, there are lunch options to turn to instead. And the outdoor patio overlooking the garden can be gorgeous if London weather ever cooperates.

HCvKt2BHuGU8dl16IWY8-g.text: The place itself was very elegant but food and service were not. I had afternoon tea with rose and earl grey tea. I remember only liking the tea and clotted cream/jam. The biscuits tasted like fast food  biscuits, finger sandwiches were a little less than mediocre, and desserts were not good at all. The afternoon tea is overpriced (yet one of the cheapest in London..). Go here to get some cute pictures but expect to be still hungry / unsatisfied afterwards.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

S8iq8FHQXM2MA-54fW7dVw.text: The Orangery is a small gem on the side of Kensington Park, just up from the palace. I like the high ceiling of the dining room with its ornate ceiling trim. It was we were having lunch in one of the wings of the V&A museum. There was plenty of space for our pram. The atmosphere was peaceful and relaxing.I thought the food might be second best to the setting, but I was pleasantly surprised. We both ordered the pork belly. This was nicely done. It had lots of tender meat and it wasn't too fatty. The meal came with apple mash, green beans, fennel and a decent piece of crackling. The flavour combinations were good and it was a decent lunch.My wife was feeding our new baby and they offered to hold her meal in the oven until she was free to enjoy it. This was good initiative from the server and much appreciated.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Grand, spacious dining room.

hXs2IVuMvG8eylEt1WPOMw.text: Lovely, bright and white! Walk into this place and you feel you're in airy and lavish looking restaurant. However, you soon realise everyone from all parts of the world are enjoying it. Parents trying to control their kids, tourists taking pictures whilst enjoying a coffee and then there were the likes of me who came with his friends, dressed up for an afternoon tea.The tea was not bad but not inspiring. With scones, jam and cream, tuna and vegetarian sandwiches. It was your basic afternoon tea. Is there such a thing as no-thrills afternoon tea?The service was a little poor, considering the place was half empty. Let's not forget they forgot my friend's order... A big no no!

hJwKM5ooqBtYxcYYmx4BQQ.text: ENGLISH TEA TIME at a cute tea room in the middle of the beautiful Kensington gardens, which means this experience comes at 22 pounds per person for a pot of tea & 3 tiers of delightsI got the earl gray blue flowers tea which was great with sugar cubes--finger sandwiches: the 4 diff types were all good--two large scones: paired well with the thick clotted cream & jam--petits fours: there was a variety of which each person gets 2: macaron, canele, chocolate tart, or eclair, they were okay--slice of cake: the most dissappointing itemthe bathroom is outside around the back but you must ask a worker for the code!NOTE: casual dress is accepted, even jeans!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. afternoon tea set for 2 people
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. our afternoon tea set for ONE person

40h8pA_5alTi2TahY545ew.text: Gluten Free ReviewI was so excited to come here! The Orangery's Yelp reviews are better than average and I rarely eat anywhere without checking Yelp reviews first. The Orangery is nestled in the gardens of Kensington Palace. It's beautiful. I paid £27.50 for afternoon tea and £2.45 for a delicious Old Fashioned Lemonade. Here is how The Orangery advertises their gluten free menu online:           Afternoon Tea with no gluten-containing            ingredients           Assorted sandwiches, sconey bun, almond moon            cake, shortbread and brownie           £27.50 per personI don't know what The Orangery's regular afternoon tea menu is like, as I dined alone, but THE GLUTEN FREE AFTERNOON TEA WAS BEYOND TERRIBLE.-No "sconey bun" or anything to replace it-No fruit preserves (probably because there were no scones)-No "assorted sandwiches". I was served six wraps instead. (The kind you can buy at Tescos for £4 - not exaggerating). There were three kinds of wraps. I was served two of each. They weren't bad but I wouldn't describe them as good either. They were edible. One was black Forrest ham - it was okay. Another was vegetarian - not very tasty. And I'm not sure what the third was. I wouldn't buy these from a convenience market for £4 unless I was hungry, had already shopped multiple locations and had given up on quality or taste. -No "almond moon cake, shortbread and brownie", instead I was served a fudge-orange bar (was this the brownie?) and an oatmeal-cranberry bar with cream. (The cream was very good but couldn't fix the desserts, neither of which were any good). I ate one bite of the fudge one, didn't enjoy it much but took a second small bite to decipher the orange part of the taste but I didn't eat anymore of it. The oatmeal one was okay but the whole experience was so underwhelming, I was not in the mood to continue it. I verified with my server that this was all I was to expect of the meal, asked for my tab, paid and left. The Royal Tea Blend was excellent but that's hard to botch.If you eat gluten, this place is probably pretty good or it wouldn't have such great reviews but if you are gluten free, as I am, I don't recommend eating here. I am rating The Orangery One Star because the service was prompt. I apologize for not including any pictures. I didn't even think about Yelping when I received my meal. I was so disappointed upon my food's arrival, I didn't want to remember it and I definitely wasn't going to send home pictures. I was embarrassed that I was spending so much for so little. I should have just paid for my Lemonade and walked out.

CfN_mOti08R4xDzqV1ElbQ.text: We were looking forward to Tea at the Orangery for weeks prior to our trip to London. Beautiful setting of course. The food was fine, but nothing spectacular. All of the staff was friendly and courteous EXCEPT for our waiter. Older man with buzz-cut graying hair. Took our order and never came back ONCE.  He even avoided making eye contact when he walked by. Our plates and glasses sat empty on the table for 20 minutes or more. He seemed to have a chip on his shoulder--maybe he dislikes gay guys or Americans. I say this because he had no trouble attending to all of his other tables.  We had to ask another waiter for drink refills and the check.

pqJRN2pjrSYtk88M1pWjQw.text: Sooo good! The high tea was a great experience and you can enjoy a couple different teas. The space was clean and bright, not to mention you're at Kensington palace! Beautiful views and delicious teas. Enjoyed it twice during our 1 week stay in London.

AI8amzWruHo7XJmN74oxYA.text: I truly enjoyed my visit to the Orangery for afternoon tea. It is one of my favorite experiences from my time in London. The space is bright, airy, and soft with beautiful views of Kensington and the gardens. The Pimm's cocktail we had was delicious and refreshing. The tea, Darjeeling, was superb with the great milk and sugar cubes provided; and all in those cute cups! The food was excellent; you could honestly skip lunch and just wait for this. The sandwiches were great; my favorite was the mini bagel with salmon and cream cheese. The Orange and current scones were DIVINE! All with the clotted cream and jam. And the cakes and dessert puddings were just delightful. Of course, this is a pricier experience,  but compared to most other places High Tea this is very reasonable. Keep in mind, this is an experience as much as it is a meal. High Tea is more formal, but the Orangery is pretty casual; understanding many people there are travelers with limited clothing options.The service staff is very friendly and made us feel comfortable. I spent 2 hours just sitting and chatting and enjoying. I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful High Tea spread!

lJWUsLtQOOWenh6QdlxUxw.text: Loved my breakfast here. Food was very good but not life changing. Atmosphere and location are simply the best, impeccable service within view of Kensington Palace.

5BaLiGPwfoP_1rsOqgI8eQ.text: Summary: a very bad value for price.This is how I look at it: you either go to a high end place, pay a lot and get great food with good experience or you go to a cheaper place, pay not much and get goodish food.The Orangery offers very bad pre-made stuff with mediocre service for medium price. The scones/cakes/cream/jam are supermarket quality and tea is served very cheaply (they leave the leaves in the pot instead of strainer which makes it become bitter very quickly).The location of the place is great but it's cheaply decorated. Despite all of this horrendous service, they charge 27 pounds per person (including service charge). For this price you can get a much better service in any of the tea rooms in one of the downtown hotels.(The high end price is around 75 pounds per person and the lower end price is 6).

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Very bad quality supermarket pastries with medium prices.

TE9MZdzqgFsYMEnnmhpYww.text: Although it was pricey, it was worth it for the ambiance alone. We did the traditional afternoon tea. All the sandwiches and pastries were excellent. My particular favorite was the scones. The weather was nice so we sat outside to view the gardens, which was lovely. However, midway through we had to move inside because the bees were drawn to the jam at our table. But the happily moved us inside with no problem.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Tried to take a lovely photo of our table setting, but my boyfriend got in the way. Haha!

oQGtKFq_vZjKQDty_U92bg.text: I had a sorority sister in town, so we decided to go the Orangery for high tea. We went when we were able to sit outside due to the nice weather! A real treat for Londontown.The service was a bit slow at the beginning, but was made up for in the end. I had the traditional English breakfast tea. My friend had the one with berries, and we were both treated to more than enough to drink. The food is delicious- plenty of clotted cream to go around. Moderately priced!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

5hGNmKnT-ttJhJKKX_0s7Q.text: It only took me two trips to London to make it to afternoon tea, and I'm questioning why I didn't do it sooner! After touring Kensington Palace, my friend and I were hungry and wandered over to The Orangery. We were significantly underdressed for the occasion, but the servers turned a blind eye to that. The china was absolutely adorable and the food was delicious. For £27.50 per person, you get a selection of sandwiches, scones and pastries and your own tea pot. I'm still searching online for a place where I can buy the Earl Grey Blue Flowers tea we had - it was delightful. All in all, this was an amazing experience - I just wish I had been dressed to the occasion!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The assortment of goodies that come with afternoon tea.

-s3XSwvVed7-aL6ejcMO-A.text: I'm not a huge tea drinker, but I figured when in Rome....This was our place of choice for afternoon tea while holiday-ing in London based on a recommendation from a friend who studied abroad here. It's certainly picturesque with pretty views of gardens and the park and the weather while we were there in April was perfect. We arrived just before closing and the line wasn't too long. We grabbed an open table on the patio and watched many people walk away disappointed shortly afterwards as the place was closing for the evening. We had Earl Gray and Jasmine tea and split a scone which was delish. It was quite relaxing and perfect to fill our tummies with snacks before continuing forward to Notting Hill. The bathrooms were indeed around the building with an entrance from the outdoors. It definitely felt more like a tourist destination. Good tea introduction, not too expensive, but if I did it again, I think I might go all out to a hotel for a more luxurious experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Earl gray tea, jasmine tea, and a scone

HiCZFNj4yiIyMBUnwX1uCg.text: This was a great way to introduce my husband to afternoon tea. Solid sandwiches and a variety of nice pastries....it does book up quite quickly. The atmosphere was lovely after our plane. Would definitely do it again.

yzjWHxvB6z1Fsm-JouI0DQ.text: Not enough servers to handle the crowd, host was too busy cleaning tables to seat guests.  Service was so slow and wait staff seemed stressed.  After waiting 20 mins we left.

usFAnUL8n7Xf-lkVFehgIQ.text: Thereare no reservations necessary. However at peak times, you can expect to wait10-15 minutes to get seated.Pricesare remarkably low. Your penny worth it, you get finger sandwiches, scone withbutter and jam, and pastries. You also get you selection of tea, of which Ihighly recommend their Orange tea. Weeven shared a slice of the Orangery cake, which is unique to Orangery anddelightful to our taste buds.

KSkVtdErRV_PbAw9n3D7rw.text: Speakingof Tea, for me it is one of the greatest places I experienced are. The Orangeryis located inside the Kensington Palace grounds. There decorations are colorfulpleasant to the eyes, sunlight streams through the tall windows and the viewof the lush green gardens is delightful.

4SsS1uCKfqaDsOudbUK4_w.text: PC W. is absolutely right--come to the Orangery for high tea at a reasonable price.  This was on my mother's short "must-do" list during our visit, and we made a good choice.  The setting and service were just as elegant as we could have hoped, and the food and tea were quite good, too.  My mother upgraded to the champagne version, and we switched desserts, which gave us both exactly the combination of food, drink, and sweets that we wanted.Just a stone's throw from the tea room is a stunning garden (see photos).  Of course, it was early August, but that didn't diminish my awe.  The entire grounds of Kensington Palace are lovely, but this island of floral fireworks was very memorable.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

eTUwMNNvlvu1Nls2GBQWyg.text: My best memory of London was at The Orangery. Picturesque garden, tea, desserts....what more can I ask for?!!Definately a must if you're in London. Just come early to avoid the line.

hRX9mpjp1xLniwGmAeK4YQ.text: 2.5 stars. This place is way overrated and overpriced for what you get! Although the atmosphere is quite lovely, the treats just weren't satisfactory. I was looking forward to especially the clotted cream and scones, but the scones were much too soft for my taste -- they were like buns! The clotted cream also had an off consistency and were quite salty. My friend said that it wasn't even clotted cream but butter. Major disappointment because those are such big components of afternoon tea. The cakes and other treats looked pretty but tasted bland.However, service was overall polite, accomodating, and helpful. They let me sit at a table and wait for the rest of my party (I ended up waiting for over an hour). The waiters were still attentive (a couple checked up on me), but I never felt pressured.My flat mates and I really wanted to like this place, but we all felt that Harrods afternoon tea was the best! Maybe we were just spoiled from the all-you-can-eat, but their afternoon tea is amazing.Pros: The chocolate-orange tea was unique and delightful to try.Nice location at the center of Kensington Gardens.Overall pleasant vibe and service.Cons:The "clotted cream" (too salty/buttery) and scones (too soft/soggy).Bland desserts.The price/portion ratio -- lacking a bit for what you pay for.

B7OWWO3cSuFlaVsE9ze2XQ.text: Our first afternoon tea experience in London. We sat and no one said hello to us for ten minutes despite multiple servers making eye contact.  Finally I waived down the hostess who normally just brings people to the table and not take orders.  He took our orders because he saw that and felt bad.  Many tables empty too.  Is this typical?  Off putting and disappointing to the say the very least.

PVk075r4X7YDyIjtoCUcvA.text: Didn't have to wait long at all at 4:30 in the afternoon for a table for two. Beautiful views of the gardens, and the price was pretty reasonable. If you're expecting the most amazing scones and pastries ever, you probably wont' find it here. But for a reasonably priced tea experience, this place hit the spot. The service was attentive (but then again, I think the waiter was hitting on me because he kept checking me out. I noticed our level of service was better than most!). Would definitely return. I love afternoon tea!

qFBBx6odPzE0ELin3glYug.text: On our last full day in London, my husband and sons went to the British GP (which didn't interest me in the slightest), so I chose to tour Kensington Palace and have tea at The Orangery. I think I won, but the hubs might disagree.  Anyway, the spot is easily accessible via the tube, and the palace and gardens were a delight, and the tea was just the thing to top off my perfectly British afternoon.  I was a party of 1, so they seated me in the back room.  This was just fine with me, as the space  is lovely and full of windows.  The service is impeccable, and I chose the Lady Grey tea, which was delicious.  It's Earl Grey brewed with blue mallow blossoms.  The tea is the only choice you have for the tea service, but that was just fine.  Three tiers are brought to you each with different sweet and savory treats.  The first tier was finger sandwiches, of which the cucumber and mint was my favorite but all were lovely.  The next tier was scones and clotted cream (so decadent!), and the third tier was the sweets.  There was a lovey meringue with a strawberry that I fell for.  All are reasonably sized, so that helps with the guilt of trying (or finishing!) everything. They were closing early that day for a private function, but I never felt rushed.  The only thing I was missing was a female companion, but mine were all here in the states!  I highly recommended this as part of the British experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. A lovely sampling of sweet and savory treats presented in very bespoke fashion.

aR8vQ_jpiauojI-4kb01jg.text: After my visit to Kensington Palace, I walked towards The Orangery for afternoon tea. The exterior of the Orangery which was built in the year 1705 looked almost as huge as Kensington Palace! It looked very upscale and there was a large green grass covered that was perfectly cut; good enough for a PGA golf match for sure. There are many benches towards the entrance too, so the exterior environment is very park like. Once I entered The Orangery, I realized that this place has an upscale environment which looked better than the interior inside Kensington Palace - what a shame eh? On another note, The Orangery was built by Queen Anne, so you are dining at a Royal establishmentI decided to order spicy cinnamon tea. Not too daring, but more interesting than earl grey black tea. The tea was served with an individual tea pot. Honestly, it looked like something one would use to water plants.  I'll say there was about about a quarter of a litre of tea, and it came with a small container of milk for the group. I could really taste the cinnamon and it was rich, warm, and a tad spicy, even with the added milk. The first item to eat were raisin scones with cream and raspberry jam.  The scones were soft and buttery, and with the added cream and jam, it tasted quite heavenly. The second item were the sandwiches. There were a variety that were cut into little finger size portions: cucumber, cream cheese and chive on poppy seed bread; poache salmon and dill on onion bread; and slice ham with grain mustard mayo on sun blushed tomato bread. They were garnished with something which looked like clovers. Honestly, the sandwiches were nothing amazing, but the bread was very soft and it was nice to eat something that wasn't sweet. I should mention that the breads on the various sandwiches tasted like plain white bread, which was rather disappointing. The last item was their signature orangery cake. It's a yellowish cake with yellowish icing with orange shavings inside. It tasted lemonish and orangey. Nice, but not extraodinary. Service was a bit of a miss. The waitress acted like she was in a hurry and she ended up dropping some of the utensils on the floor. Service was quite rushed, and maybe I'm too harsh for something who just travelled in Paris? I mean, they literally took 5 seconds to hand out tea, milk  for four people in my table.  Total price of the bill? £50.12 which was pricey, but it was a memorable experience, thanks to the bright classy interior.  I'll honestly have to say that I enjoyed the tea more than the food. After the meal, I had to use the washroom. Interestingly, the unisex washroom is only accesible by leaving the front entrance. It's located near the side of the building. You will need a numeric password to enter it - they're not for the public! Inside, each of the huge toilet stalls has its own sink, soap dispenser, and towels. Strange, but it works!

CEOWK3bv1wfKyXOvHhgt0Q.text: Came here for the first time with my boyfriend and it was an absolutely wonderful time. We were seated promptly by the window and spent most of the afternoon there. Drinks were great. Especially the pims and eucalyptus tea.

sHH1f98LKsm1Cok6o-zz1w.text: Not very good food.  The room is beautiful and the service bad, extremely slow. I was very disappointed, as I had great expectations for a restaurant inside Kensington Palace.

VoguGmTRmLUrVaFrxZBOUw.text: I wanted to treat my girlfriend to an afternoon tea. After doing some research, I came across Orangery which was highly recommended for its nice setting and it's great location in the park. We had a pleasant time and enjoyed all the great treats. One quick tip - spend 2 min and make a reservation online so you can bypass the 30 min queue on the weekends.

q83Xd9C4AeXeVP3LJg1isw.text: We came to the Orangery for high noon tea and I don't really know any other reason to come other than that.  Anyways there was no wait when we arrived and we were promptly seated outside.  Soon enough, contrary to what you'd expect in London, it was hot and bright, so we asked to be moved inside and the staff was very accommodating.We each ordered the same afternoon tea samplers that came with finger sandwiches, scones, and little desserts (oh, and of course tea.)They are very upfront that the food does take awhile to come out which is mysterious as you'd think they could easily churn out cucumber sandwiches, but alas this was vacation so I didn't mind waiting.  The food was very good and the butter was whipped perfectly.  My tea was hot and I had enough for about 3 solid cups.I would highly recommend the Orangery even though it is a bit of a tourist trap but unless you are having tea at Buckingham Palace with the queen, I don't see you getting a quainter, more relaxing experience elsewhere.

zbZs1p2c-YPNCFbD9WCnJA.text: Must do!  Tea service is wonderful.  Friendly, attentive service.Wonderful teas.  Wonderful ambiance.  Tasty food!Expect to wait a bit.  Not sure if they take reservations, but we just showed up and waited in line.  Maybe 20-30 minutes?  Worth the experience.  Beautiful gardens!

RvOQG76VMbXwUQUoaZKWng.text: 3.13.10, We went to have high afternoon tea here.  Sandwiches = good.  Scone = delicious orange-ness.Eclair= cold heaven.  Orange and passionfruit tart=ZOMG.  I'm still dreaming about it...*droool*Tea, it was okay.  It was not as strong as I had wanted and I'm still not into the milk plus sugar thing.  lolService = efficient but lacking any friendliness.   :(  Decor = grandeur old-school white beauty  (If you see pictures, you shall know how truly white it is!)Prices for my tea was around 15 quid, and his carrot cake with lemonade was delicious, so he says (for under 6 quid). :)Of course 'service' was added to the tab........10%The restrooms are interesting...go outside and punch in their access code.  lol Before or after tea or both, go for a nice stroll.  It's right near Kensington Palace.  Unfortunately, this March, it was closed so we missed out but the park was just beautiful, especially as we saw it closer to twilight....:)

a5UnPW-1h5h2doQH1LSF1A.text: Blueberry muffin and 'wholemeal bloomer' were pathetic.  The first was dry and flavorless, the latter was literally just thin store-bought white bread, ever-so-delicately burned and dried out, served with nearly frozen, unspreadable butter.  Cranberry & pecan cake was overly sugar sweet and not flavorful.Fresh mint tea was poorly presented and needed double the mint.Ham & cheese croissant was pretty good.Service was friendly but literally could not understand anything we asked for. Usually a language barrier is extra easily forgiven, but at the very least, staff should understand the things written on the menu.  I can't imagine how difficult it must be to get through a day at work not even understanding basic ordering, especially with the vast variety of languages and accents that must pass through this place.  More staff-training, please!  That poor guy!On the positive side, the space is quite pretty and the white... everything... is refreshing.  On the negative side, we were there right after opening, and the door was covered in smudges and hand prints and... goo... from the day(s) before.  If you can't keep your all-glass front door clean, what does that mean for the rest of the joint?

KtKtUbKlsbozAPcbSIOx3w.text: Amazing scones15 pound tea better than 1812.5% service charge included in final bill

ThTFsjykWlaSsBtDOjTg_Q.text: Afternoon tea at the Orangery is a lovely (and affordable: £26.00) weekend experience. Fairly priced, you don't feel guilty about splurging and adding on a glass of wine or champagne. The grounds are beautiful, especially the walk to the brick building where you pass through immaculately trimmed hedges and zigzag bushes to get to the main dining hall. The expansive ceilings give an airy and light feel to the space, and the lily-white walls and lattice windows opening to the patio and garden add to the relaxed and classy atmosphere. The lighting is amazing (no irritating or blinding glare), the royal china is delicate and beautiful--a faint Tiffany blue with gold, and the sweets and savories are made fresh so you won't run into any dried bread or stale scones. Presentation is simplistic and classy. Add-on options: Pimm's, champagne, wine, etc.Sweets: orange and currant scone with clotted cream and strawberry jam, chocolate and jam cakes, lemon and chocolate mousse. Savories: egg mayonnaise, chicken wrap, smoked salmon and cream cheese mini bagel, and cucumber and fresh mint sandwich.Drinks: loose leaf teas, infusions, espresso drinks, miscellaneous cold bevvies like ginger beer, lagers, and juices. The waitstaff never made us feel as if the affair must be rushed, so we didn't have to hurry along with our drinks and fare. Reservations highly recommended as the line to get in can range from an hour to two, especially midday on weekends. Patio seating beneath umbrellas is an option as well.

wUcvbr1Kr5b3uTLFs2mTeg.text: Afternoon teas at the Orangery was the perfect introduction to British's high tea culture.  We wanted to go to see the exhibit at the Kensington Palace so didn't have several hours to spend at a nice hotel for high tea. The Orangery provided the perfect compromise - trying afternoon tea treats and seeing the exhibit.  It was also quite reasonable about £28 (vs £50-75 at hotel) per person.  Plus, we got to sit outside and have a nice view of the garden.  Ana was the nicest waitress we had experienced and she made it extra special.

The staff were attentive and informative.The only fault I found was that the bathrooms were located outside of the restaurant and a little walk away which i felt was odd for such an upscale place.

1kjYQ8a89b0bYtnGssAvaQ.text: Strolling in Kensington Palace and surrounding by formal gardens, you might want to match the beautiful scenery with elegant British high tea. The orangey is a perfect spot to enjoy your leisure afternoon. I ran into this place while strolling in Palace. Without the reservation it took me around 10 mins wait to get a seat. My high tea came with three layers: Assorted sandwiches, sconey bun, almond moon cake and shortbread. Palace breakfast tea with milk. Just like average high tea.Sitting next table there were British girls celebrating sweet sixteen. Some tourists like me on the other end just sipping the tea and spacing out. Service was attentive. Nice ambience as well. I came here a year ago and defiantly will come back when I visit London again.

cvaUWw8S8nVBK8f5E0SUFQ.text: I'm a tea lover and while in London it was imperative that I experience a proper afternoon tea. A friend recommended The Orangery situated right next to Kensington Palace. As a tourist with a tight schedule, I loved the idea of killing two birds with one stone.  I made a reservation online for 3pm on a Friday. My mom and I were seated as we arrived in the all white room with high ceilings. We opted for the English Orangery Afternoon Tea for £26.00 per person. The china was beautiful and the ambiance was lovely. I chose the lemon and ginger tea and my mom selected the wild berries tea. The tea was accompanied by a three tiered tower of mini sandwiches, scones, and sweets. My favorite selections of food were the scones, chicken wrap, and the lemon mousse (or whatever it was). This was our lunch for the day and we left feeling satisfied. I especially enjoyed being able to sit, relax, and admire the view of the perfectly manicured palace garden. We weren't sure how fancy to dress, so we went with black dress pants and cardigan sweaters, others were dressed more causally. I imagine this place would be a great location for a bridal shower or brunch. If only I lived closer!

KIBF-Pw5UyyXjG7e1i-oKQ.text: The Orangery was one of my favorite places to eat while in London. Whether you decide to have a British tea or a meal, you won't be disappointed. Friendly service, lovely atmosphere, and the beautiful grounds topped off the delicious meal I had. Take the time to visit the gardens nearby, and Kensington Palace!

J0ChhT16Zfo1AvSkTCnyIg.text: Such a joy to come here for breakfast. They have gluten free and it was amazing. Got see into the new princess di white garden before breakfast. So nice that they keep her memory alive. The dishes were darling and the tea was divine. I had eggs Benedict and the hollinasise sauce wAs killer. Service was great. So beautiful a location. Obama was there the day before and it messed with reservations but we got in nicely and walk ins even fit in for breakfast by getting there just as it opened.

HRPFXXbCrKfY5W3Xy1mmrw.text: The Orangery offered a lovely afternoon tea. Our reservation was at 16:00, we arrived 10 minutes early and were seated right away. We chose to sit outside as it was beautiful weather. The location is wonderful, and it is just behind Kensington Palace. I ordered the afternoon tea, which was quite delicious. The tea came with several different kinds of fingers sandwiches, I particularly liked the coronation chicken roll and the ham and mustard. Biscuits, one plain with dried fruit and the other orange scented were on the next plate. The final plate had a macaroon, clotted cream, and a small cake. I particularly liked the clotted cream. The table was set beautifully. The plates and cups were of gorgeous pattern as were the views. I am pleased with my afternoon tea experience and hope to go back on a future trip to London.

AMG7U1JsDv2isNQKOv6a1g.text: Afternoon Tea in a historic British setting? Yes, please. Built in the 1700s, The Orangery has a rich history of its own, while sitting next to iconic Kensington Palace. The Afternoon Tea served here was fresh, modern and at a reasonable price. The setting can't be beat. You can sit inside or out with a view of the gardens. Can't go wrong with either. Our server was polite and helpful, even asking to take our picture. We opted for the Royal Afternoon Tea which included an adult drink (Pimms or Champagne). The tea sandwiches, scones and pastries were all delicious. I'd recommend making a booking, especially during the summer months. Definitely one of my favorite afternoon teas in London!
