qGtDRgiECzGdDgT4Mg7JFA.text: Nothing bad to say about my afternoon tea I had here last Friday. Great service, delicious foods, and even better tea! Welcoming and enjoyable atmosphere, with high ceilings and posh decor. You can't beat the views of the garden, so ask for a window table.

IoTpKesQfzPHL7oC1V4Fdw.text: Pretty view in the gardens or they would get even less stars. Very subpar food and service. Waiters didn't seem eager or even pleasant to serve. The eggs Benedict and royale were kinda gross.

QUPuxluNlKNBotyXCgtB9w.text: Had a horrible experience without the experience. Attempted to go for tea with a friend while visiting London and we weren't able to make a reservation on the website so we called various times with no answer, no answering machine and no information on walk-ins for tea. Finally decided to call the Museum and they said to just come in as they do accept walk-ins. Tube was partly down in our area so had to take a bus then tube over but once we got there, they were closed that day for a private event. Annoyed that they had no notice indicating that on their website or phone message, or informing the museum staff to avoid this situation. The real horror is the fact I emailed the manager of the restaurant and facility and never got a response. I emailed about 5 separate times only to receive automated messages saying they are away on vacation then to be forwarded another email. I'd then try emailing that one and never getting any responses. I eventually started to get aggressive in my emails demanding a response as this was ridiculous for a restaurant and still no response. I can't believe the lack of customer service and would not suggest anyone to go here or hold an event here due to the staff and service or lack there of. In my experience I never once spoke to a single soul no matter how many times I called or emailed, very embarrassing as I've never experienced such bad service in life anywhere I've traveled.

v9Z6ZwbMWuo9RFOGLprgeA.text: There is no other better place to get afternoon high tea then in this beautiful garden and former royal residence. Yes, it is extremely pricey but as I was visiting London, it felt like the price to pay. Getting to the Orangery is a bit of a long walk, so definitely add in at least fifteen minutes before if you have never been here before. There are a variety of teas and I was excited to see a green tea option because Europe is all about their black teas, which I am not the biggest fan of. The high tea option didn't come with as much food as I thought it would. For two people, we had a single three tiered plated contraption. At other tea places (albeit in the US), it would be one per person but oh well. The cream and strawberry jam is so delicious. We smeared everything all over our scones. The sandwiches were atypical. Their mint sandwich bites have less cream or mayo then other tea places. There is also a more expensive option to have champagne instead of tea.You're paying more for the atmosphere than anything else. It's not the best food or teas I have had but one of the nicer places I have been for high tea. The staff was really nice and are more than happy to take pictures for you. What better way to prove you've been here than pictures, obviously?

1v6zKTl-Cs6WkAb0aDCrPQ.text: I would advise you not to use the restroom at The Orangery. A man tried to videotape and photograph me in the bathroom. It was horrifying and traumatizing. The same thing happened to another female restaurant patron, and we both complained to the management. The management took little to no action to rectify the situation. They said they would find out who the perpetrator was via security cameras, but then they claimed that "the perpetrator must know exactly when the cameras are turned away" and did nothing further. If this is indeed the case, then, this type of incident occurs frequently at The Orangery, and I would advise you not to use the restrooms. This occurred during my afternoon tea so needless to say, I did not enjoy my tea. At the end, I was still expected to pay full price for the tea. The management did not offer a discount or anything to make them seem sorry for what had occurred. While it is not their fault, I was expecting them to it more seriously that there is a sexual predator targeting their business, to fully investigate the issue and offer some level of empathy.

h2bBcrBepbqBB0GEbl0miA.text: This was a very nice experience. The staff was extremely friendly. At first they did not think they could find a table, MAKE RESERVATIONS!Champagne with the tea was fab! It's call the Royal I believe.

FFQXCK9IZUMvHouZCMzm1A.text: As someone who is absolutely in no way an expert, I was completely 100% thrilled by tea at the Orangery! It felt elegant and indulgent, the epitome of luxury and grace. Food and tea and every last crumb was just exactly what I'd hoped for. Doesn't hurt that the space is gloriously lovely.

aRZH_f4xME32CLrI6YoG0Q.text: The husband and I recently took a trip to England to attend a family wedding and stayed in London for two days.  Traveling from Hawaii and being my first time in London, there was so much that we wanted to see that at times I felt like I was being dragged by the hand while running around non stop.  It was a nice to slow it down a bit and to enjoy an afternoon tea at Princess Diana's former residence.  We chose The Orangery because it was the most affordable afternoon tea in comparison to other places like Harrods.  There was a bit of line to get in, but it moved quickly and definitely was worth it.  The inside of The Orangery was absolutely gorgeous, white walls, high arched windows, white statues, a beautiful view of the gardens, and an absolutely adorable tiny orange tree at the center of each table.  We both ordered the orange tea set which came with the following: orange flavored tea (I haven't tasted better tea yet), orange scone with Cornish clotted cream and strawberry jam, an eclair, an orange passion fruit tart, and an assortment of salmon dill, cucumber and cream cheese, and ham finger sandwiches.  We had no complaints as all were delicious.  It was a great experience and I would love to return here!

-qZ0wSp0q5Ephf7zNxG7JQ.text: Has a really fantastic, soothing ambiance being in the park (like a downscale Tavern on the Green) and is worth checking out once you agree that High Tea is fantastic and want to move on from F&M.

OGJuaUeUEAQuNEORa9t_9Q.text: I LOVE this place. Besides having such an amazing atmosphere that embodies the English tea tradition, the food is good! Not only are the scones with clotted cream and jam delish, but the seasonal soups with fresh bread are so perfect on a rainy or overcast day. The tomato soup is so good it must be laced with msg or something. Was here about once every two weeks during my 4 month stint in London. Look forward to going back on my next visit.

9fB4w68RI2hHJEKQtdPH9Q.text: Fun fun place to have high tea.  As soon as you walk in there is a huge display of cakes and cookies.  Great cheese plate.

UzZvXiYeembzkFzVSEVM-A.text: We loved it. Early lunch in winter. I had been here for a mid morning tea in the autumn and had one of the  best pots of Earl Grey I have ever tasted - Palace Earl Grey and ogled the food that other people were eating. This time we ate and drank - a very nice a reasonably priced Australian Cab Sauv which went perfectly with the braised in stout beef cheek and the venison and boar sausages. Light as a feather mashed potatoes glazed carrots, perfect Yorkshire pud with the sausages. We shared, we liked it a whole lot  and then we had . The bread & butter pudding was extraordinarily good - oh yes, it was and I shouldn't have had dessert and if were going to, I shouldn't have chosen the raspberry meringue with cream and berries. It was delicious but stop me next time, OK? Very good cafetière coffee - just a very small glitch with timing. Otherwise, very good service from start to finish, friendly, attentive and not pushy. Great way to break a walk around the Parks. Go for lunch, or for a small snack and a glass of wine

WP1kd1gxsx_T_oIjYa7hig.text: The setting was really pretty. It was well worth the wait. Couldn't believe that the line was already down a quarter of the walkway right around 3:20PM (which is right when this place opens). But I was able to take plenty of pictures of the area while my friends waited in line. We took the outdoor seating which actually wasn't as preferred by other people. 2 parties turned it down to wait for a table indoors. The selection on the menu isn't large. The prices were pretty expensive too running around 15-27pounds a person. But it was my first time and the view is gorgeous, so why not. We each got our own tea sets, I got the Debutante tea. I ordered Earl Grey and it turned out very lovely. The finger sandwiches were less than par, in my opinion, but the scones were very scrumptious. The clotted cream and fruit preserves really balanced each other out. I wasn't able to finish the chocolate cake that came with mine. It wasn't as sweet as it looked but I was stuffed by everything. It also seemed like a regular chocolate ganache cake. I'm sure I would've been able to get better tea somewhere else, but it was a wonderful first experience.

JZCEz4hqyG2-Pipwln9lpQ.text: We visited this restaurant late Summer this year it was a lovely sunny day and we took the option to sit outside although it started to get quite windy during the process of our meal. We made the mistake of going of having lunch at mid day as they didn't serve the famous afternoon tea until later in the afternoon. We were dissapointed with this but that life I suppose. We opted for the lunch as we had walked all the way to it through the gardens and could not be bothered going back to the Kensington High street restaurants as we were hungry. The lunch menu is quite limitiing but the meal that we had was healthy and nice. the staff were very attentive and pleasant to deall with. Would visit again but in the late afternoon for the afternoon tea.

WlhwWJJwBaPrdNaZtlEcNA.text: The main thing I wanted to do in London was make sure I went to "high tea". The atmosphere can't be beat. It's beautiful with wonderful bright windows. What can be beat is the service. Completely lacked any sort of personality. We were never checked on after we ordered. Just simply took our order, delivered the food, and then was never seen again. We even had to get up and go find someone to pay. The food was delicious and we enjoyed the experience but I would probably find a different place to experience English tea next time I visit London. Also the bathrooms are outside, around the corner, and you have to have a key code.

JI1nUPfDmG8e6stIpKfhNA.text: When in London... You must have afternoon tea! And what better place to do it than at the Kensington Palace? I really enjoyed my time at the Orangery. I recommend making a reservation. It is accessible with the tube. The tea room is so lovely! I like the high ceilings and wide windows. We sat by the windows and it was really bright and sunny. At one point, I had to wear my sunglasses. We came here for the afternoon tea. Each person gets his/her own tea pot so don't worry about compromising on the tea to order. I ordered the organic Chinese sencha and it was so fragrant, light, and soothing. If you like green tea, I recommend trying that. My favorites from the tea set are smoked salmon and cream cheese mini bagel and cucumber and fresh mint sandwich. The staff members here are very attentive and friendly. The only part I did not like about this place is that the restrooms are outdoors, which makes it a little inconvenient. After the afternoon tea, you can take a nice stroll around the garden and Kensington Palace!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

KaS21S_ym-GHzHaJowzNPg.text: When in London, one must have afternoon tea. And what better place to have afternoon tea than The Orangery at Kensington Palace, the residence of the British Royal Family since the 17th century?I made a reservation in advance and wandered around the gardens in the palace on my way to the restaurant. The restaurant is very grand with tall ceilings. It definitely feels like I was one of the royals. While I was at the restaurant I also learned a brief history of how afternoon tea came about. It was back in the 19th century when Anna, the 7th Duchess of Bedford complained of a "sinking feeling" in the late afternoon. Back in the days the British had 2 main meals during the day, which was breakfast and dinner. Anna then had her servants bring in a pot of tea and some light snacks for her in private in the late afternoon. Then later, Anna started invited her friends over during this hour to join her for afternoon tea and snack. At my visit in London, I got a taste of enjoying tea at the royal palace!For £27.50 per person, you get a nice selection of sandwiches and pastries and a choice of your own tea pot or coffee. The scones and pastries were amazing. The sandwiches were delicious. I especially like the ham sandwich. For some reason it reminds me of the sandwiches in Hong Kong, which is heavily influenced by the British because it was a British colony for over 150 years. I got the earl grey tea and it was lovely and paired well with the food. The service was also really good. The server was attentive and courteous. I am also a sucker for people who speak to me in British accent. I was overall impressed by my experience here!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Tea set
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for 2

aw8lMi3MU7ZKVaukAGyVXw.text: The Orangery is situated amongst the gardens at Kensington Palace. The decor whispers elegant simplicity; there's something sophisticated, but not stuffy, about the building's high ceilings, grand pillars, & beautiful crown molding. Afternoon Tea here (£27.50/person) was a lovely occasion. Tall windows offered direct views of the outdoor surroundings from our table. I chose Lady Grey tea, a sweeter version of Earl Grey made with blue flowers that went so well with milk & sugar. He ordered lemonade. Our three-tiered extravaganza arrived with various sweet bites like amazing marzipan tea cakes & mousse topped with meringue; scones; & crustless sandwiches (with the ham & English mustard being most delicious & the coronation chicken being my least favorite.) Was surprised to not find crumpets a part of this carb fest. Sidenote: bathrooms are located in a separate area outside of the restaurant; being your coat if it's nippy out.

PHefb3YIu-_t3dH08xSaDQ.text: As a tourist in London, this is the place to have high tea. This was probably one of the more expensive things we did in London because it was an authentic experience, but it still didn't run us too much, maybe $50 per person for everything. We ordered the basic tea and food package per person and split a bottle of rose, which was perfect.Recommend making reservations and going during the afternoon, so you can also walk around the Kensington Gardens and Palace.

pWy5t38A_LGcbKSK90o9tg.text: My wife and I came to The Orangery for afternoon tea while on vacation in the UK. The price per person was fairly high at 27.50£/person ($40/person in USD), but we knew that going into it.The Orangery itself is situated just outside of Kensington Palace in a separate building near the gardens. The building and interior is very classy, yet casual. There is nothing "ornate" about it, but you feel like you're in an upscale setting. From my American perspective, it's everything I would have envisioned for an afternoon tea in London.We ordered the "English Orangery Afternoon Tea" and received all of its accompaniments. My two favorite things were the smoked salmon & cream cheese on a mini bagel along with the coronation chicken wrap. The smoked salmon was perfectly tender, the cream cheese very creamy and light, and the mini bagel was incredibly soft and fresh. The coronation wrap had incredible flavor and was seasoned with a mix of Indian seasons which caused the flavor of the wrap to "pop" over the menu items.My wife and I were able to eat everything they brought to us and get full, but if you're extremely hungry know that this will not be an entirely satisfying experience. It's afternoon tea so it's not intended to be a meal substitute. As for tea, she went with the Palace Breakfast which is their strongest black tea while I enjoyed the Royal London blend. Overall we had a great experience with excellent service! And for my wife, it was a "London bucket list" item so I'm glad we did it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Sipping that Royal London blend tea and looking fancy
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The Royal Palace tea.

tTWdriyRMHFnS8Sn44I-0g.text: Gorgeous gorgeous place in the middle of the Kensington Palace gardens. You honestly get what you pay for. The service is impeccable and the afternoon tea is very good, albeit expensive (€30+). However, you get the full shebang -- three tiers of beautifully plated sandwiches, scones, and cakes, and a pot of tea for each person. However, for the atmosphere, location, service, and quality of food, I thought spending this amount was justifiable, despite being a stingy American. Please come here and try out this place on a warm  sunny day!

buHTX3MzppvjsWLqkALqYQ.text: Nothing bad to say about it really. Came here with 5 girlfriends after having made a reservation. Great service, delicious tea, sandwiches, muffins and cakes. It was all what I expected high tea to be like! Plus the space is awesome. Would love to be back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

PTEc9mx90JI2wD6Fgrbqqw.text: Great afternoon tea with the most beautiful atmosphere. I enjoyed all the sandwiches and desserts. The only bad thing I have to say is that after I was sat, it took about 20 minutes for someone to even come to the table and greet us.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

kRQx6_Sb6IzweNOLjL9u-Q.text: Took a stroll through Hyde Park with this as our tea time goal. Beautiful setting with a view of Kensington Palace. Tea was really nice overall - very filling but almost too much dessert. Scones and  clotted cream were perfect. Sandwiches were a bit bland. We may have over ordered  by ordering two Afternoon teas but we each wanted our own pot of tea. I would say this is a must do for the setting and experience if you are visiting.

C-oDxx6ZtFtvJuMp-5M3JQ.text: Best English afternoon tea experience of my life, on the grounds of Kensington Palace none the less. Afternoon tea at the Kensington Palace Orangery is more than the royal pattern on the plate settings, the silver silverwear, the proper tea serving, the perfect little sandwitches, fluffy scones, rich jelly, and creamy butter perfectly triple stacked on a vintage stand, the Kensington Palace gardens one strolles thru to get to the Orangery.  It's the magic of the English Afternoon Tea experience at the Kensignton palace when it all comes togerher that is memorable.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

hvqlHeGhzJowgEbgfal6wg.text: Who doesn't want to have tea at Kensington palace? When in London, you must get the whole high tea experience to learn their culture. I came in at around 3PM-ish, got seated pretty quickly. The waiter I had was a little snooty, I guess he was over serving tourists. I got earl grey tea with pastries. The pastry tray had three tiers, the butter was OMG good and the scones were yummy. The thing I didn't like was the sweet desserts, they could have been better. The finger sandwiches were yummy as well. They might not look filling but these tea snacks will fill you up. Prices were reasonable compare to high tea at the Ritz! I think mine was around $27

JZ8ndGtZybJ49bYSsHuu9Q.text: Touring Kensington Palace and the gardens, is a perfect occasion for an English tea experience.  The tea room is lovely!  Very palatial with tall ceiling and lots of windows for natural light and a view of the grounds.  We opted for the traditional tea.  They also offer tea service with champagne.  The pastries were lovely and the scones were delicious!  Scones are my favorite.  The finger sandwiches were tasty as well with a good variety of salmon, cucumber, chicken curry and  egg.  Crusts cut off of course.  :-) The tea was good and served on lovely "royal" china.  Service was prompt and friendly.  I recommend making a reservation to ensure you get a table.  It was a truly fun experience having tea at the Palace.  An ideal thing to do while visiting!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. High tea

hXuRXDy8lgz9iZvxVPaXmA.text: We had to try this place for it's history we where very pleased I didn't want to leave but had to catch a plane to Paris

EzqsLKFdztYidb-43xWr9Q.text: It was pretty packed when we arrived with no reservation but we were seated right away by the window with great garden view. I was surprised. I always get lucky with my wife around though! The waitress said sometimes you have to wait an hour+ My wife and I had a lot of fun here. If you are traveling, you should try the 27.5/person afternoon tea experience (you probably will agree it's a great deal if you're from the states). This is what give you the three tiered set of finger sandwiches, biscuit, and desserts - eye candy. And most importantly, tea refills if you're jittery from low caffeine, or... too much of.. Also, if you care about photos as much as my wife does, you'll be satisfied with the beautiful tea set, the people, and the desserts :) Hope you stop by to enjoy the exotic herbal scents travel gracefully from your nose to your tongue with each sip My 5 stars: for overall experience and friendly staff.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea with my lovely wife. & Beautiful table setting.

1zeDcR3qvZHLCsGP50p0KA.text: Tourist trap that I welcomed. I just wanted to use the pretty china :) Came for breakfast because tea time was overbooked. Food was as expected - just okay and pricey. Tea was as expected - good quality. Service also as expected - attentive but nothing over the top because they know you're a tourist.

gfvnigQyf8i_iQ8trtTeHg.text: If the afternoon tea service is too expensive for you (although it does seem lovely), consider breakfast or lunch. We went for a breakfast, and it was such a delight! We got the eucalyptus zest tea and the wild berry tea and both were wonderful! Highly recommend. Also got the eggs benedict, which had a delicious hollandaise (eggs were slightly under salted), and a croissant with ham and mature cheddar. For an after breakfast (or dessert if you believe in dessert in the morning) we had a cheese board and the berry crumble. The cheese came with a delicious apple jelly.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Eggs Benedict with a ham croissant in the background
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The cheese board and berry crumble in the background

naKhxmvXSQiJeTh0UPktKw.text: I was planning on eating at Harrod's after our visit to Kensington Palace, but hubby needed to eat.  Not impressed by the quick gift shop cafe we had walked through the gardens to dine at The Orangery.  The hostess did tell us they were closing around 2 for a private party but we were seated (and others after without being rushed out).  We were seated in the far back smaller area.  I had imagined this restaurant being very grand looking since it is inside the palace, but it's very white and stark, reminding me of a museum with simple columns and a few statues.  Our waiter took awhile to take our order.  Not too much appealed to me honestly, so I ended up doing another afternoon tea ($27.50 GBP).  He went for the mint, pea and truffle risotto ($13.50 GBP).  The silverware was very grand though.  I enjoyed the tea sandwiches but I think most places give an extra sandwich or so.  The assorted tea sandwiches included an egg salad, a smoked salmon, chicken wrap, roast ham and english mustard sandwich, and a cucumber mint sandwich.  The middle tier consisted of scones, and the top layer contained three sweets: a macaroon, a small cake and a lemon curd shooter topped with a meringue cookie.  I went with a berry infusion tea which was light and very fruity (just how I like it). The smoked salmon was about two bites, but delightful.  Egg sandwich, chicken wrap, and mint and cucumber sandwiches were good but nothing out of the ordinary.  Didn't care for the ham sandwich.  The scones were light, fluffy and moist.  I always enjoy the clotted cream and jam too!  Lemon curd with the meringue was a little diffcult to eat but it was refreshing.  We enjoyed the macaroon and mini cake slice later on as we took it for take away.  I'm used to a little more variety whenever I go out for tea honestly, but the quality is there at The Orangery though.  As for his risotto it sure was plentiful.  We couldn't taste much of the mint, but the consistency of the risotto was pretty spot on and the truffle was light as well.  The risotto had a ton of peas in it.  We wished service was a little more attentive, but overall it was a nice lunch break at such a wonderful palace tucked away in the serene gardens.

VtCn2Ji3SI-No4PscOohmg.text: I enjoyed my afternoon tea in the elegant dining room at The Orangery at Kensington Palace which was a garden pavilion built for Queen Anne in 1704. Great service. Loved the wild berry tea and the Laurent-Perrier champagne. The finger sandwiches were delicious. The cucumber-mint was unique and surprisingly good. Terrific service! Please get a reservation. Kensington Palace is on a security lockdown for a week. You can't go onto the grounds without a reservation. They serve lunch, tea, and cakes. orangerykensingtonpalace…

ia5G3QktnlBtLCbJS-owqw.text: The location and the building were beautiful, but that's all that they have got going for them.The food was disappointing. The scones were good, the sandwiches sub-par, and the desserts were absolutely inedible.Service was dismal. The waiter acted like we was annoyed by us and barely spoke to us. And, this is not the restaurant's fault per se, but there were two girls sitting by us who took selfies for about 30 minutes straight with the sound turned all the way up on their phones. The constant sound of a camera shutter was enough to ruin an already disappointing experience. The waiter should have told them to at least turn the sound off on their phones.I would NOT recommend coming here.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for two.

8Q8QqNbQcl5TCJR3Ar1ROA.text: Very grand setting. That's the first thing you will notice. High ceiling, elaborate crown moulding, columns and statues, with windows looking out on to Kensington Gardens. All white, so yes, on one level is can be stark, but from an historical perspective the clean white was a show of wealth too - look how clean we can keep this.  We only had the tea and scones, so I can't speak to the full tea, but what we had was most excellent, and just the thing for something to sustain you after a busy afternoon in The City.  Take the time to walk through the Gardens, too.  Definitely a highlight for my time in London.

1v00OO0V9OfJ_DvRxFde5g.text: Came here with some friends for afternoon tea. Ordered the signature orange tea set which came with tea, signature orange scented scone with Cornish clotted cream & strawberry jam, an éclair, and an orange and passion fruit tart. The finger sandwiches came in an array of different kinds but it all tasted a bit...eh. The cucumber sandwich in particular was really....... nasty. The cream cheese inside tasted really off. The scone on the other hand was delicious!!! Especially with the clotted cream and jam. It was nice, moist, and flavorful. The tarts were a little too sweet. My friends whom ordered the same as I couldn't finish it too as it was overtly sweet.

6TFUO2r_EPuM2A-rorxcng.text: We stopped into this place when we arrived in Paddington station on a train from Heathrow. To sit with a pot of tea in the front of the shop and people watch passers-by as you daze out post red-eye flight is an unexpected comfort. The place is artsy and casual, and I wish there was one like it down the block from my home in the states.

dtMNDmx_7pGThZGtoiL11A.text: Beautiful! Great service, delicious tea and snacks. Incredible Kensington gardens is your view as you snack and sip tea. A must  for tourists and Londoners alike.There is always a wait so be sure to be on time/early for tea or don't bother. It can be quite touristy but there's a good amount of locals. Including the ever popular "ladies what lunch" crowd of London's uber elite upper class.I met up here with friends who were studying abroad. I had recently graduated from college/uni. We met up for tea and had a reservation thankfully. The best part besides the atmosphere and tasty treats was that I was able to share this with friends I had known since the age of  5 and 6. A truly wonderful experience!

YZU5KqRerXBsHncOTal7Gw.text: I've only been here in the winter (February) and it was absolutely beautiful. We were too early for the tea menu so we made our own with the sampler plate and a slice of cake and a pot of tea.

_AVixVh9fj93KizDpryZ2g.text: YES! Can you believe this place made me love tea after disliking it for years?! It is possible. Or maybe I just refused to sip any sort of sweetened tea with yummy flavors (flavours?) before I stepped foot inside this island paradise.I went to London for a bit last summer to study abroad, which was the best decision I've ever made; I had an amazing time. This was one of the reasons why, and the first time I went here (because some of us went twice during our three-week stay) was one of my favorite days out of the entire trip. Four of us visited Kensington Palace and then walked briskly over to The Orangery. One of our pals left because she wasn't feeling well, but the three of us ended up having a pretty lol time. Our waiter, whos name I completely forgot, was really cool. My friend had a huge crush on him! She would talk about him our entire meal and every time he came by they seemed to flirt a lot, and he would always say something to us like "That's because you're American!" or "That's what women do!" He was kind of cute though, and I figured he was a wannabe model or actor type, and when my friend had the guts to give him her number after our meal, she told us he was indeed an aspiring actor with dreams of attending drama school at NYU someday. Go, you!Anyway, I believed I ordered "The Orangery" meal (maybe they changed it to "Signature Orange Tea"?), which came with "an assortment of finger sandwiches" (it was so qt, I think it was the cream & chive sammich) and a small, delicious scone. I also had a random small wiener/pineapple/cheese deal, which my friend ate because I find it uncomfortable when sweets are mixed with meat. Anyway, we obviously had our choice of tea, to which there are a lot, & even though at that point I wasn't really a tea person, I ordered a cinnamon spice tea. When it arrived, I admittedly dumped it with sugar cubes but holy hell it was beyond amazing! I think I drank my entire pot of tea. :/ My friend ordered a mint tea which looked like a giant green plant was falling out of her tall glass, but it tasted good as well. We all enjoyed our meal and took pictures like any young tourist. I completely forgot what I had for dessert, or even if I had any at all.After our great experience, we walked around Hyde Park and talked. It was a great day.The second time I went, I met up with more people, and basically ordered the same thing (sexy waiter was nowhere to be seen!), except for dessert I remember ordering a gluten free chocolate hazelnut cake. Definitely did not taste the gluten. That was really good. I completely recommend anyone and everyone try this place at least once while visiting or living in London. I suggest taking a nice walk around Hyde Park afterward, as well. Thumbs up!

souoWAj65ULmjvqKsS5Vog.text: Die Orangerie liegt in den Kensington Gardens in der Nähe des Round Pond und des Kensington Palace. Das Gebäude selbst ist sehr schön, korinthisch Säulen, sehr stilvoll und elegant. Die Einrichtung des Restaurants passt zu dem eleganten, hohen Raum. Schön die kleinen Orangenbäumchen, die sich auf jedem Tisch befinden. Wir waren zum Afternoon Tea dort, der extrem gut besucht war. Es ist eine bunte Mischung aus Touristen aller Nationen, aber auch Einheimischen. An der Qualität der angebotenen Speisen gibt es nichts zu mäkeln. Dass der Afternoon Tea mir nicht zugesagt hat, lieg vieilleicht einfach daran, dass das Ganze für normale Mitteleuropäer viel zu üppig und Fett ist. Scones mit Clotted Cream - einmal im Leben probiert, brauche ich nie wieder. Dafür kann allerdings die Orangerie nichts. Punktabzug gibt es für die Bedienung, die zumindest an unserem Tisch überfordert wirkte und unaufmerksam war.

jdZgcyJEKPH5kk2jzeTDjg.text: Here thou, great Anna! whom three realms obey, Dost sometimes counsel takeand sometimes tea. With these lines Alexander Pope forever linked in my mind Queen Anne and tea. So it is only appropriate that Queen Anne's little palace conservatory extension at Kensington Palace (1704, Sir John Vanburgh designed, no less, and three times over budget) now houses one of London's great places to take afternoon tea. The Queen's orange trees were housed in a sumptuous baroque space  soaring ceilings, windows and Corinthian columns; classical statuary and Grinling Gibbons carving. Apparently, she hosted al fresco summer supper parties here as well, hence the decoration. The all-white space works well for the modern café, with its rows of decorative metalwork furniture and dainty miniature orange trees on the tables. It seems to aim for the luxe tourist and/or well-heeled local; it is so nice to see this sort of thing being done well in this sort of location. The café certainly lives up to its elevated architectural surrounds. Service was very friendly and obliging but perhaps a little off-focus: but the place was hopping all afternoon (Anne and I settled in for a lengthy gossip over pots of tea and cakes; there was no pressure on us to move out) We ordered the exclusive Tregothnan tea  the first tea to be actually grown in England (in Falmouth). One has to applaud the ambition  at 50º N it is the most northerly latitude at which a tea garden has been planted. However, great flavour requires high altitudes and  even as someone who prefers weak tea  I found this one slightly underpowered. Our cakes included lemon meringue (a generous slice with a tart lemon curd filling and just right crisp and chewy meringue topping), chocolate fudge cake, and an apricot and almond slice. A plate of prettily arranged dainty finger sandwiches included cucumber, smoked salmon and ham. A very successful afternoon, and I am sure Queen Anne would approve of her Orangery's modern incarnation. I'd definitely go again.

5x2Xntw3H7sFfKnpLV2Q0g.text: Okay, I'm an American, so that makes me entirely unqualified to be a skilled judge of which place has the best tea.  So based entirely on my own opinion, the Orangery was a thoroughly enjoyable experience.  Located adjacent to Kensington palace and in the middle of beautiful Hyde Park, the Orangery provides a wonderful selection of teas to go along with a delightful assortment of little sandwiches and pastries.  The service was attentive and friendly, without being bothersome.  This is a unique skill that the staff was masterful at performing.  The overall price, compared to other establishments, was truly fair and worthy of the enjoyable experience.

sA9NOImBAcc9zQ3q9LGF9A.text: This place was gorgeous. It had excellent tea and deserts. The experience one of a kind.

y1UTLPt5RuuDTYjZs7L9jw.text: Loved the beautiful grounds, sumptuous building.  I went here with a friend as I had read good reviews and wasn't disappointed.  We were in London with perfect weather and stopping here was a real elegant, relaxing meal in the midst of our sightseeing.  The service and the food were top notch.  The bathroom you do have to walk outside the building and have a code which could be annoying if the weather was foul.  We also went to the Langham Hotel for High Tea, but I really found this to be more relaxing and enjoyable.  When I returned with 2 friends the next month I took them here and they also enjoyed the experience.

ZgExjZh4FhuG9mBQY5JtDw.text: The English sure do know how to do tea! The setting here is beautiful and relaxing. We just stopped in for a snack in the afternoon (tea time!) and we were able to get a table right away...granted it was a weekday. For 5 people we ordered the English Orangery Tea set which came with a variety of tea sandwiches, orange scented scones with clotted cream and jam, a variety of tea pastries and the Royal London Blend Tea. We all got a small taste of everything so if you are actually stopping in for a proper tea, you might want to order more. The tea was, of course, delicious. With a touch of cream and sugar it was perfect with all the finger foods. The sandwiches were fresh and flavorful. The scone was fragrant and perfect. I looooove clotted cream, it is so good especially with the scone and jam. The pastries were ok but a nice sweet touch towards the end of tea. The 5 stars is primarily for the environment you're sitting in. The grounds at Kensington Palace are beautiful, especially the garden. You get a great view because of all the tall windows at the Orangery. And there's a certain fancy feeling you get just knowing that Princess Diana once lived there. I would definitely come back.

oAGBBaYJOrlksRuP4nJNig.text: Why American Tourists Get a Bad Wrap in a Foreign CountryBy Amanda H.Here I am, enjoying a beautiful afternoon tea with my lovely Joe L, me sipping on a pot of cinnamon English Breakfast Tea (I'm putting cinnamon in all my tea from now on!) Joe a pot of the Tregothnan. We are munching on a delicious fruit scone with just the right combination of clotted cream and jam. We are sitting outside enjoying the beautiful weather and the gorgeous view part of the gardens. Out of the corner of my eye, I spy a rather heavy set woman and her friend sit down at the table next to us. I continue nomming on my scone.Woman who is CLEARLY American, on the phone: OH MY GOD YOU WILL NOT BELIEVE WHAT I'M DOING NOW!!!Joe and I: We both blink and look at each other, and then at the woman out of the corner of our eyesWoman who clearly needs to get out more: I'M HAVING AFTERNOON TEA....AT KENSGINTON PALACEJoe and I are clearly embarrassed for every American ever as other person around her are beginning to stare and move their chairs away.Woman who won't get off the damn phone: YES I'M DRINKING CHAMPAGNE AND I HAVE ALL THESE DELICIOUS GOODIES AND I'M JUST GOING TO STUFF MYSELF SILLY (You think I'm kidding as I write this? She literally said that)At this point my right eye is twitching because she's called literally 5 different people and is being loud and obnoxious and crying about how much she misses being home and blah blah blah someone stick a knife in her PLEASE. I'm trying very hard to enjoy the delicious lemon cake that is sitting in front of me. The frosting is deliciously sweet and crunchy all at the same time, and this fat woman is hindering my experience. I feel bad for the woman's dining companion since she is being utterly ignored.After another 5 minutes of this I resolve that if she calls another person so-help-me-God I'm going to freak out on the lady. Joe and I are trying to hide the fact that we are American, because at this point, having to somehow connect ourselves to that stupid stupid woman is making me want to hand over my American passport and start screaming bloody hell where ever I go. Thankfully, I think she receives my telepathic screams to shut the hell up, and gets off the phone.The end of our rather enjoyable afternoon tea ends with questions of "Do WE act like that?" And breathing a sigh of relief that no, we do not carry a sign that says "YES WE ARE AMERICAN PLEASE MAKE FUN OF US"The End.

E3o8kF2tCet5IpWgME-38A.text: I usually don't care much for tea but having a proper afternoon tea at The Orangery was such a neat experience, that I'd absolutely do it again and again.  For about £15 (per person), you get your choice of tea, 4 very small slices of assorted sandwiches, a scone with clotted cream and too-sweet jelly, and 2 dessert pastries.  Clotted cream tastes a little bit like butter but lighter.  Personally, I prefer my scones with creme fraische, which was how it was prepared when I had it at a friend's house.  The ambiance was really pretty but our server was just alright.  I expected a lot more politeness from a place like this and I didn't get it.  NOTE: This place is actually located inside Kensington Park and there are no signs on the building.

lmWH1Rsp5IecCB6pw7fkNg.text: $25USD for about half a sandwich in 4 little strips on the bottom and orange scone in the middle and a couple of desserts on top.  It was good but pricey for what you get.  I think they do a better version here in the states...they always have larger portions in the U.S.

PS8Z4EjzwBPzv_W-xQYXRw.text: Get here early because a long queue begins to form at 3 in the afternoon!  My sister and I both had the "orangery tea" which consists of: cream cheese & cucumber sandwich, cake, and fruit scones served with clotted cream and strawberry jam.  If I can remember correctly, everything was delightfully presented and delicious.  I immediately made the decision that I should adopt this tradition when I returned to the states.  Unfortunately, that never happened.  I can always refer back to my experience here at the Orangery when I become a domestic goddess and have time to prepare afternoon tea!

gCi2CEkoi70XmY7YRPA2Ug.text: Ok, so I am just an American who studied in London for 4 months (so what do I know about tea?) but I will just say this place was really lovely, and quite a good deal. I knew I wanted to try a real tea service, and I'm so glad it didn't cost me a fortune. The cucumber and cream cheese sandwiches were stacked elegantly, the scone with clotted cream was warm and delicious, and the tiny piece of orangery cake to finish off was perfect. I really miss Hyde Park and this beautiful little place to have some tea. I had cinnamon and it was wonderful. Hopefully I'll be back soon!

vr2iAX1l_TGtkMtplFYC8g.text: Long lines? Yes. Expensive? Check. Worth it? Absolutely! Sometimes a gal just has to treat herself and afternoon tea at the Orangery on the grounds of Kensington Palace (former home of Princess Diana) is just the way to do it.  There usually is some kind of wait, but honestly it's not more than the wait at popular brunch places in NYC. And the experience is better than any brunch I ever had in NYC. The long waits are not due to the bungling waiters or food taking a long time to be served. It's due to people not wanting to leave long after they have finished eating. Maybe they should take note of popular NY restaurants and impose a time limit. The scenery of the grounds and the atmosphere of the restaurant itself just makes one feel fancy. The English Breakfast tea was great (tea leaves only here, no tea bags), the scones with jam and clotted cream were the best I ever ate on any side of the pond, and the finger sandwiches and little cakes/tarts were delicious.  I also found the service to be polite, friendly, and impeccable. For example, one of the sandwiches had ham in it and the waiter saw my scarf and knew automatically not to bring me pork. When I asked what was in the sandwiches he said, smoked salmon, egg, cucumber, and ham, but you don't want the ham right?  He brought me 2 smoked salmon sandwiches instead. In the US I always have to spell out that I can't eat pork so I was pleasantly surprised. Anyway people in the UK just seem to be more culturally aware and accepting, but I digress. The Orangery is worth at last one visit and I know that whenever I'm in London again I'm heading right over.

lJnE_3CSh99F7JiWrBEjyA.text: having arrived at 2:30 in the afternoon, we couldn't order the formal tea (strictly served after 3pm only). but the friendly server suggested that we create our own tea by ordering, piecemeal, items off the menu. my husband is a savory lover, and a lover of cheese, so he was inclined to order the cheese plate, which meant i was allowed to choose the cake! our cheese plate consisted of a creamy, delicious mull of kintyre cheese, quince jelly, celery, and duchy oatcakes. i choose the orangery signature cake-the orangery cake-a spicy, citrus cake with creamy frosting, which i chose from the dessert table near the main entrance. i don't know who could resist after seeing all those cakes and tarts! it was hard to choose only one, but i went with the signature...which seems to be a good idea usually. as the orangery is a member of the british tea guild we each ordered a pot of loose-leaf tregothnan afternoon tea (grown in england), extremely high quality and delicate and delicious.as we sat and enjoyed our little meal together in the 18th century green house for growing oranges, we took in the stunning details of the room...with the floor to ceiling windows, it was bright and airy. a beautiful building, a fabulous place to have tea before a walk through the gardens.

kQy_pxaqqZHdMnNhMHkhwg.text: Delightfully delicious. Love the scrumptious pastry plate with the bouquet of flowers adorning each table. The wait is long but worth it. Plenty to ogle at while your waiting.

V8_yCHjTmKe_30bDRTedFA.text: We stopped for tea at The Orangery while touring Hyde park and Kensington Gardens this afternoon. The restaurant is under renovation, so they temporarily moved the tea spot to the Pavilion at Kensington Gardens.Even though the venue was basically a huge tent used as a temporary restaurant, the tea and pastries were still quite on point. The scones were warm and fresh. The sandwiches came in wheat bread which I didn't mind but my fiancé hated. Only thing I didn't love was the tea cakes on top - they were overly sweet for my taste. The service was superior - the waiting staff made sure to check in with us once in a while since we were seated in the corner. They were also quite fast with the order.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

GvI0dthv7__wsXUwFhVUaw.text: Sadly the Orangery was closed for renovations, but fortunately, betwixt it and the Sunken Garden is a rather posh pavilion set up to serve lunch and high tea like the Orangery used to do.  I had wanted to take my family there for high tea (to recreate a memorable tea that I had there on a visit 25 years ago), but was quite happy to settle for an elegant lunch at the substitute pavilion that took its place (until the Orangery is back on its feet in 2020).  On this visit, we opted for lunch rather than tea - although the tea offerings looked most tempting.  But we went with the French-influenced lunch menu and had roasted duck breast or a roast chicken with tarragon mushroom cream sauce, scalloped potatoes, and sauteed greens.  The meal was delicious and elegantly presented by a courteous and polite wait staff, and it was a most relaxing experience.  We felt like royalty amongst the  crisp white tablecloths, the view of the Sunken Garden, and the gloriously clement weather.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Delicious elegant lunch of roasted chicken and mushroom cream sauce
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The posh temporary pavilion serving lunch next to the Orangery

BVjZZ7T_z5hFVUlSushARw.text: An afternoon tea experience is a must while in London. At The Orangery afternoon tea is served from 12:00 to 18:00. You have your choice of English Orangery Afternoon Tea (tea only) or Royal Afternoon Tea (add a glass of booze). Boyfriend chose a black tea, Afternoon at the Palace, while I went with a class of Merlot Rose Spumante. The drinks, sandwiches, scones and pastries were all amazing. Tip: Make reservations in advance.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Royal Afternoon Tea
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

QQCJq21wC9KYsD-55U-Vyw.text: Steps from Kensington Palace and Gardens, this is a perfect pitstop to your day of sightseeing. Come here to check off high tea from your list of to-dos in London! Great ambiance and fair prices. My friend and I both ordered the orangery afternoon tea set, which included assorted finger sandwiches, scones, a small dessert pudding of some sort, and of course, tea! The sandwiches that stood out for me were the smoked salmon with cream cheese, egg mayo, and one with curry chicken. I ordered a green tea and my friend ordered the oolong. The oolong was my favorite, but both were good. The raspberry fruit pudding (?) was small but I really liked it. Ambiance of this place is great. The space is really open and large and it feels like you're outdoors with the big doors and windows. The view is awesome - you're looking straight into Kensington gardens. Prices were very fair compared to the other high tea places in London which can go for £60 pp. The orangery was about £30 pp but so worth it for the experience. I'd recommend this place to friends visiting London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

ZyFAqmvMvZ4YZdxqwHnChQ.text: I've had many great afternoon teas at The Orangery but after my visit on Oct. 24, I will not be recommending this place!  We ordered no salmon but got that kind of sandwich anyway, the bread was a heavy wheat grain with hard to eat seeds in it, the plain scones were orange flavored, the mayo and egg sandwich were frozen and crunchy.  Not worth the £30 I paid for the nasty tasting experience.  The tea was steeped to perfection but just couldn't over ride the rest of the experience.

xVniLE904t8LaZiotuMGFw.text: It was on my tourist to do list while in London.  Done that and I wouldn't repeat.  If I knew what I know now, could have saved major bucks and didn't even bothered with it.Atmosphere: nothing to note or talk about.  Bright, spacious and tall ceiling.  Does that count? Food: basic. Very basic.  Service: very slow * plates are worn out. Toilets are outside and looks unsafe.We were greeted professionally and seated by the window over looking the garden toward Kensington Palace. Nothing special but better than seated next to the wall. It was still cool so out door seating was not available.  We opted for the afternoon tea for two.  It took while to come back with our tea.  Food took even longer and I was worried my tea would get cold.  Yes, that long.Yes, we were there to experience the EXPERIENCE  but there was nothing to experience.  My money down the drain.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. 64.12 For basic afternoon tea for two.  Cucumber and mint sandwich was to be avoided
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. For two
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea

SOBWkkucLhOQJeKIL54XbA.text: What a fun experience . We loved reading about the history of tea before entering, and enjoyed the tower of finger sandwiches and desserts as well as tea.

Gmkvhhj0V6OZp-eIPTD1BQ.text: Strangely enough, I thought this place was just ok in terms of afternoon tea. Caveat- vegetarian review. And I've only ever experienced this one, so it might just be me.View & ambiance- great. Spacious place w/high ceilings & lots of space between you & the next person. View of the lawn near Kensington Palace/Garden was nice (not every seat will be near a window, though).Vegetarian afternoon tea: Tea- best part. The teas all have different flavors and if you ask the server, they can help give you details. Comes with cream & sugar if you want that. You get 1 pot and one type of tea. Sandwiches- just ok. Cucumber & mint, cheese & what was apple? Or pear? Egg salad that was pretty bland, tomato and something or other. Bread was your average white bread. Biscuits- came with some jam and clotted cream. Both were pretty good. Not outstanding, but quite good. Desserts- kind of, boring? Just ok. 2 out of the 3 were mousses. The last one was a cake that was just, normal. Nothing memorable. Really not worth the cost.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Tea selection
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. English breakfast
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast menu

wMsxSS8qylx-DgthBrWy2g.text: My friend and I stopped at the Orangery for a traditional afternoon tea. It's nestled on the edge of Hyde Park, next to Kensington Palace. We had a great experience, as it was one of the few places that offered a "gluten-free" afternoon tea in London. I got the traditional afternoon tea, with scones and finger sandwiches. It was delicious and the tea was perfectly brewed!Everything was served on beautiful glassware and the view to the gardens was unbeatable. Staff was excellent, especially with my friend's gluten allergy. Although a little pricy for afternoon tea, it was very enjoyable!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Traditional afternoon tea on the left and a gluten free afternoon tea on the right

VF3Wwimt7Vj9uTk5TfV1iw.text: A truly incredible experience at the Orangery. $28.5/ea for high tea is so absolutely worth it. My favorite part was the scones & clotted cream and the breakfast tea. Everything was made perfectly and tasted wonderful. You will be so full you will not be able to move. Overlooks the Kensington Palace in a beautiful setting. the service  is perfect & our waitress OFFERED to take out picture (she must have known we were tourists itching for a good photo). You start with one tea and if you finish your pot, a refill is free of charge. If I am ever in London again this will be a must.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

yjjuw7_0R-_oKtu0D_Jh-w.text: Amazing amazing amazing restaurant! The scenery and ambience just doesn't compare. High tea is a must here. Walking the gardens and inside Kensington were just spectacular. Beautiful setting and makes you feel like royalty looking out at the castle grounds sipping fancy teas and devouring delicious scones!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

8x4Z5kdt_m-ywr14FLOq8g.text: BEST tea experience I've ever had (without a doubt preferred this over Sketch and the Plaza in NYC). The highlight of my London experience! Not only is the location stunning, charming, and regal, but the prices are affordable and the tea food itself is actually good. Amazing scones, to-die for desserts, and killer cappuccinos (you can opt for coffee instead of tea during the "tea" itself which I appreciated). The staff was nice, not rushed, and truly made our group of young twenty-somethings feel like princesses. Another bonus is that you can make reservations online on open table... so easy.Highly recommend popping into Kensington Palace itself (and the gift shop!) before/after tea. This was an unexpected detour but the history and charm just emanates and will add to the tea experience!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Traditional tea- amazing food, excellent prices, and stunning setting- you can't beat it!
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccino- simply gorgeous!!

QhJMdn4LWGF_1V3qwnHYjg.text: The Orangery is the perfect place to indulge in a traditional English high tea experience after a visit to the Kensington Palace and Garden.Tip:  Admissions are required only if you visit the Kensington Palace.  If you visit only the garden and the restaurant, no tickets are required.The restaurant is elegant in a way that is simple yet sophisticated, but not overly opulent.  The vibes are relaxed, cool, and unpretentious.Service was a bit slow in the beginning.  We were seated for about ten minutes before our server greeted us.Our server did apologize for the wait and she was upbeat and friendly.  She offered to take pictures for us with the high tea setting which I think was a very nice gesture.  She offered to do the same for other customers too.  So I'm sure she is used to doing this numerous times a day every day.  In fact, she is a pro - she took some very nice pictures for us at the perfect angles!An afternoon tea set comes complete with the following:-- A selection of finger sandwiches which include turkey and cranberry, ham with my favorite English mustard, egg mayonnaise, smoked salmon, and cucumber & mint.-- Two different types of freshly baked scones (that day we had a plain vanilla one and a currant scone) served with English jams. (Compared with American jams, the English version is usually fruitier in taste, only lightly sweet, and not sugary.)-- An assortment of pastries and mousses.  The day we were there we had a slice of Christmas fruit cake, a key lime mousse, a cherry pastry among other goodies.  The fruit cake, with a rich aroma of rum, was very yummy and was my favorite sweet of the day. -- Your choice of tea or coffee (when in England for high tea, forget about coffee and order tea.)  If you like a very strong cup of tea, try the Palace Breakfast which is a blend of Assam and Ceylon black teas.  I personally like the Afternoon at the Palace which is a black tea with a smoother and lighter taste.It was a delightful experience and I won't hesitate for a second to do this again the next time I'm in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Traditional British High Tea.

lI4Zm-cQbDtkp_RBe58qkg.text: We had to do the traditional afternoon tea and no better place than at Kensington Palace. It's a little pricey and the tea and snacks are really nothing special but what you're paying for is the fantastic ambiance and having an opportunity to walk around the Kensington palace gardens afterwards. If you don't visit London often (this was our first time), I'm glad we had this experience. I probably won't do afternoon tea again if we ever come back so it's nice to have our one experience here.

NT7CgWmCnzhjpX40NHE_NA.text: While in London, I wanted to treat my wife to a proper English tea. Why not at a Kensington Palace I thought to make the experience most memorable?I easily made the reservations online and we made sure we dressed for the occasion. I even learned how to fold pocket squares to complete the look for my suit! Purple is my 2016 color of choice and purple shirt with purple paisley tie is how I offset the black jacket. I think I looked smashing, especially compared to a few guests, let's call them barbarians, who wore jeans to English high tea at the The Orangery. I know you can but does that mean you should? We took an Uber and splurged for a select model for once. It was nice tooling around London in a spacious Audi A6. However, we discovered finding this place was a bit tricky. Luckily, a palace guard gave us directions to drive down a pedestrian walkway and then walk through a gate to The Orangery. The interior was quite spacious and serene. The only shortcoming was the lack of music but we enjoyed our conversation instead! Lukas, the manager, was quite friendly and even forgave me my transgression for ordering a double espresso with my tea. I consumed it quickly and they took away the offending cup immediately to dispose of the evidence. When we found our table to be slightly tippy, Lukas graciously explained the building was created in 1689 and the floors were no longer perfectly level. He adjusted the table and all was well!We selected the tea with champagne course because, well, because we could! Nothing makes tea better than champagne after all! Agree? The scones and jam were tasty as well as the little tea sandwiches. The china everything was served on was truly royal and stunning in its timeless beauty! The highlight for me were the desserts which were all scrumptious! One was a lemon mouse with a meringue topping. The next was a wonderful fruit cake with creamy frosting. Finally, there was a creamy chocolate confection covered in sweet, crunchy caramel. I tried all three with no regrets!I highly recommend the experience, once in your life. Just do it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. On the palace grounds
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Serene setting from 1689
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Proper English Tea!!!

TPEsCHLX7XdcR8lRmoNbEg.text: Visiting Kensington Palace.  The Orangery is right next door.Great space.  Fast and Friendly service.  Reasonable prices especially for this part of London.  The food did not disappoint.Two of us had the Seabream with minted Potatoes while the other two in our group had the Mushroom Risotto.  I had a chance to taste the Risotto in addition to enjoying the Seabream I ordered.Both the Seabream and the Risotto were delicious.  The Seabream was cooked just right with a sauce that complemented but not overwhelming The fish.  The Risotto had good texture and flavour.  I especially enjoyed the pleasant wine essence that I detected on the Risotto.The expansive space also made lunch more enjoyable.I highly recommend the Orangery for lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Great space

Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Mushroom Risotto

fJwn6RwZA7IWKnvGZg4yKQ.text: How often can you say that you dine at a palace? What a cute little place! The place was busy, but luckily the three of us made reservations online. We each ordered the "English Orangery Afternoon Tea" for 28.50 Pounds per person, and added a bottle of rose to share. It came with 5 tea sandwiches, scones, and a selection of mini desserts. The chicken sandwich was my favorite as it was spiced with a little bit of curry. Overall, all the sandwiches were great. The scones...omg so good with a little butter & jam. The desserts were alright, but I was so full that I didn't eat all of them. My favorite dessert was a chocolate hazelnut one.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

ynJkCYT-k-5WF40PuXE0Yw.text: We came here for breakfast and it was one of the highlights of our trip! It was our first time in London so we wanted to enjoy tea somewhere nice, but didn't want to splurge on a traditional afternoon tea. We decided to come here to start off our day in Hyde park. Although it's not on the menu, they offer cream tea (scones, jam, clotted cream and a pot of your choice of tea) so just ask your server about it. I've never been too much of a tea person, so I don't have any strong preferences. I went with our server's recommendation and chose the Earl Grey Blue Flowers (if memory serves right) and it was the best tea I've ever had, I was surprised by how much I loved it. Strongly recommend. The scones, jam and clotted cream were also pleasant, although nothing too special.  My friend ordered the croissant which was perfectly flakey and delicious.The standout was the hot waffle with caramel apples and cinnamon cream. OH MY GOD. I literally have not stopped thinking about this waffle in the months since I've had it, it's that good. If you're not into sweets for breakfast then I probably wouldn't recommend it, but it's a super indulgent way to start your day. The waffle is perfectly cooked and the cinnamon cream is the perfect compliment to the apples and light caramel sauce. They all melt together for an incredibly delicious bite. It was also cheaper than I would have thought. My standards might be a little skewed being from NYC where everything is expensive, but the waffle was only £6.95 which was maybe about $8.50 at the time. For the quality and chic atmosphere of the restaurant I would have easily paid $12-$15 for that in NYC. Speaking of atmosphere, the restaurant felt very upscale although the prices didn't really reflect that (ideal scenario). It was a very beautiful setting, with the white walls, flowers and beautiful China. It was also nearly empty on a weekday morning. We weren't aware of the type of atmosphere before hand, but I felt perfectly in place in my ankle boots, skirt, sweater and black coat. My friend on the other hand wore sneakers, jeans and a sports jacket and felt really out of place (we had a long day of exploring ahead of us, I just tend to dress up normally which worked out). However, the staff welcomed us and were friendly so we felt comfortable regardless. But I would recommend dressing more on the business casual side of you want to feel in sync with the atmosphere for breakfast. Overall would definitely recommend this place for a pleasant breakfast to start your day. Great atmosphere, food and location. It was great to walk around the beautiful gardens right out outside the restaurant after our meal!

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Not a great picture but the only one I got of the space, tried to avoid getting strangers in them
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful china with our tea
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Warm waffle with caramel apple and cinnamon cream

vcQ_4KHjBrtxGPShH5nWcw.text: I had to do London tea and had my eye on the Ritz, but my husband didn't have a suit so we couldn't go there. Our concierge referred us to the Orangery and it did not disappoint!The day we decided to go for our visit was gloomy and rainy. We arrived to this nice building along the edge of Hyde Park and were greeted by the upbeat host. The room was huge, white and featured tall windows that over looked the green grass outside. Tables were lined up in two rows and had white linens. The space was beautiful.There was a nice mix of different people having tea. People that were dressed up, people just trying to seek refuge from the rain, and people just stopping in for a quick bite. We tried two different kinds of tea and I fell in love with the Royal Blend. We were served tea sandwiches, scones, and tea cakes, with clotted cream, lemon curd, and marmalade on the side. The fare was good and we were stuffed!I'd def. go back again!

4d9T9vpxpNdfH6PBT68E7A.text: Watch out for the racist manager Florence. He almost tried to redirect some people to the cafe next to Orangery instead of getting a seat for the waiting customers.  He did not bother greeting or welcoming the customers. Definitely suggest getting him fired and get a new manager who has some sense of hospitality.   But I must say sandwiches and deserts were great, if weren't for the manager the experience is pretty nice! The location has changed this one was next to the Kensington garden.

E3dKxDzpAiFzYnIviA9pig.text: Had a lovely breakfast here before touring the grounds & Kensington Palace. Cinnamon waffle was delicious as were the Eggs Benedict. Just missed seeing Prince William leave the grounds in the royal helicopter-fun time for a bunch of Americans playing tourists for a week! Lovely spot

Nkc-OdgoYDvQjfMseL0YoQ.text: The menu offered a tea set with the usuals and another set with alcohol options. Simple yet practical. Decor made me want to spend a day there and I loved that some drinks were offered with complimentary refills. Pricey but nice.

-sad4aOV2StVehjPrdgxCA.text: The Orangery is fairytale London to me: nestled at the edge of royal gardens on the Kensington Palace side of Hyde Park, it is light and airy and elegant. The food is accordingly light: quality soups, salads, fruits, desserts, tea and coffee.  It is a restful retreat after walking the London parks for hours. And no one hurries you there. You feel comfortable going there alone with a book - or with postcards and pen in hand. It is a perfect "third place" for many Londoners and visitors alike.

5KTd3BxIuRwce_hwi0jzmw.text: AMAZING place for afternoon tea. Everything was just so elegant and delicious. What's better than having Earl Gray tea next to the Kensington Palace, with beautiful little sandwiches and macarons and pastries. Just amazing!

D6_ha5Oq0gSPXSYwBVwIbQ.text: Lovely setting just outside of Kensington Palace with beautiful interiors but wasn't too impressed with the quality of the Afternoon Tea that was on offer. The spread is pretty basic and for £15 you get a pot of tea, four small sandwich slices, a scone with jam and clotted cream and two mini tarts - none of which blew me away. I'd probably recommend a slice of their wonderfully presented cakes and a coffee / tea if you want to experience the ambiance but save your money to have afternoon tea somewhere else.

h5pp5dmy26O668_7RVx6jA.text: Not bad but not great. If you are looking for the London afternoon tea experience you will not find a nicer place with perfect ambiance and setting. The Orangery used to be a green house that was converted into a tea house. It is located next to Kensington Palace and situated nicely within the garden . The tea selection is good and they have an assortment of biscuits, cakes, and food. Sandwiches were a bit stale but you must try them as they are of course part of the experience.

WvZgNKGvcdPgvQio3yyPTA.text: While in London my wife and I decided it would be a good thing to have the afternoon tea experience. We looked around at places that offer it and searched yelp for reviews, and found the Orangery. What could possibly be better than an historic royal building, we thought. When we arrived, granted snowy day in January, the building was hallow, cold and stark. No warmth, no decor, echoes from others talking, stark white, restaurant-grade plates and cups, this was not the tea we envisioned. The food actually did look nice, but we left without partaking so I am adding one star assuming it was good, but the lack of any attempt at ambiance and decor makes my review only a 2 even with giving them that freebie star. See our review of tea at the Brown hotel if you want to experience a proper afternoon tea.

f0edfQvS_OU65eSQhMmkCQ.text: When in England, do as the English.   It was High Tea all the way for this girl while trekking around London town.  I recall a recent conversation reel here on Yelp talking about the tradition of high tea so I was very interested in having a real time high tea experience with all the chichi trimmings that we've come to associate with this daily English ritual.High tea is served between 3:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m.   Many of the hotels in and about London town offer this service in their dining room.  It is all very proper right down to those little tea sandwiches.  I had presearched London UK Yelp looking for insight as to where a Canuck on the loose with a tube pass might be able to indulge in the repasse.  The Ritz came highly recommended and with it accordingly goes the price tag.  So I kept looking.  Finally I settled for High Tea at Kensington Gardens in The Orangery.  The Orangery is a magnificient room and I understand that on the weekends there is often a line up for high tea.  The menu gives you several options.  You can choose a pot of tea (yes, they offer coffee....a french press!) and pick a scone or a piece of cake off their sideboard.   You can pick one of four pre-set tea menus that have a mixture of things so I figured what the hell, I'm going for the Orangery Tea special.  This included those snooty little cream cheese cucumber sandwiches, traditional scones with jam & clotted cream and a piece of the house cake, aptly named The Orangery.   Care to guess what flavour it was? I chose Darjeeling Tea to wash this all down and the pot came with loose leaf tea, a silver strainer and a silver holder for the strainer once I began using it.  It is all posh and proper.  The price tag on this particular tea service was about $22 per person.  The Orangery is also licensed and champagne with or without orange juice is also on the menu.  In the end...what did I learn about high tea....well, I learned that cream cheese and cucumber sandwiches suck big time.  Bland and boring.  The scones however, when served hot and fresh and slathered with clotted cream are ambrosial.  If I were to do it again I'd have settled for some tea and a double order of the scones.  The room itself, the Orangery, is magnificient and is pure homage to all that is English and all that is proper.  Those china tiered plates all loaded up with tarts, sweets and sandwiches are just so pretty to look at and I had to fend off feeling a bit like a British debutant when our waiter walked towards.  What a moment, sitting there having tea, quaffing down Orange Cake and looking out on to the gardens in Kensington.  I've pasted up a couple of pics just to give you an idea of what this architectural monument to a tea service looks like.  Next time in London town, be sure to take in High Tea at the Orangery.

p68IV39f842jJQrCGxS94g.text: Take it from me, the afternoon tea at The Orangery is treading nervously between two sides of a pool - the expensive luxury tea services of classic London hotels, and the cheap and cheerful tea+cakes found in the cafes of National Trust houses and castles all over the land. The result - at £15 to £25 per person, is simply not worth it. Better to go full-on and splash the cash at a name-drop hotel or spend half-as-much somewhere like Fulham Palace or Windsor Castle.It's not that it's not beautiful here. It's a stunning conversion of the Kensington Palace greenhouse that never quite worked out (not enough light gets in for growing oranges). High ceilings, marble statues, views out into the Palace gardens and Hyde Park beyond. It's even rentable for weddings, and if you have the cash for that sort of thing, then be my guest... or rather, let me be one of your guests.But the ambiance and prestige of the location are let down by simple uncomfortable tables and chairs, rudimentary service and poor excuses for cucumber finger sandwiches which are constructed on your plate into strange jenga formations - should this be 'tea-henge'? Plus it's not exactly the Ritz when the toilet is outside in a port-a-kabin, is it?The scones are cracking though, and the tea selection is mighty cool, even featuring tea grown in England (well i never)! So that kind of makes up for the disappointments elsewhere. But not quite.The moral of the story... don't come expecting a real treat of an afternoon tea service - the luxury side can't be got on the cheap in London. Better to just treat the Orangery as a place to drop in for a pot of brew and some dead good scones.

xlhpg79jc6mcdOEkJRxY_g.text: a gem of a tea place. very proper and the epitome of the afternoon tea experience. walking into the orangery was like taking a step back to another time when  tea was the highlight of the day.  prices seemed reasonable to me especially since we were in a very high tourist traffic area. our server was a bit snooty but aside from her, i loved everything else.  scone with strawberry jam and clotted cream - where have you been all my life? this was definitely one of my favorites of the meal along with the orangery cake. orangery cake - very moist and sweet with just a slight hint of orange. yum!belgian cake - very rich and chocolatey. a bit too rich for me. cucumber sandwiches - so so. a bit mushy like they were mass produced beforehand and put into the fridge until needed.i thoroughly enjoyed my experience here.
