hdsyMaGJObkCERq0S5RTZw.text: Well this is a very cute, very historic, very tourist driven, and a must for little princesses first high tea. We thought our server was nice she was definitely holding too many tables though. Which of course in turn made our service slow. I am not gonna blame Miriam our server cause she was moving, just had to cover too many bases(more on service later) I went wimpy and just ordered a Prosecco, knowing full well the family would over order. So Rose Prosecco perfect, Bitter Ale very nice(i like the 500ml bottles), LA Croix White Languedoc perfect citrus peel on the nose. We tried to order a variety of things off the menu and everything was fairly tasty. The scones were over the top clotted cream will do that. Cheese plate was solid and the tea sandwiches were all pretty good though a little dry. All in all a great experience if you have a little princess she will love it.

lhAPzXg15bZfo2lV4JMMQg.text: What to do on a lazy Sunday afternoon with your girlfriends???shop? oh no! it's absolute chaos with all the tourists and end of summer sales. boy hunting? always a good option....but, let's grab a little snack beforehand...The Orangery has the most mouthwatering scones I've ever had. The cucumber sandwiches were perfect, the tea divine, and the place was exquisite. only complaint: the horrendously long wait for our tea and meal to be served

uB8xmveL--m6A4Srq4AHxQ.text: The tea, produced in Cornwall on the southwest of England, was love at first sip - it was light, delicate and refreshing. It came with finger sandwiches, orange-scented scones, fruit tarts and shortbread éclairs, which were delightful to look at and even more delightful to eat.

t6giRiKipi8NVg1hoV3Uog.text: Been a few times over the past year. It is nothing nearly as fancy as having afternoon tea at the Ritz or the Lanesborough but nice for a casual affair. It also doesn't cost half as much! The wait can get bad if you go at prime tea time but otherwise, it has never been more than 10 or 15 minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

R0oBk-KOIFXkKaQXum52lw.text: I was tempted to put two stars, but really I can't say I've experienced better.  This was the only place we went for tea while in England.  The positives: Pretty little building, adorable little orange trees on the tables for decoration, I had one of the best pots of Green Tea I've ever had in my life.The negatives: Really, it pretty much boiled down to the not feeling that the price we paid was really worth the experience.  Although my tea was excellent, the food was just all right.   Bf's tea was so so.  We waited in a huge line and then sat at a table right next to the hostesses counter next to the front door with the freezing wind gushing in at us the whole time.

UBOAbelQRodIRR_C6cVj5A.text: While on a visit to London from my family's house, we were hell-bent to get a cream tea. Originally, we had intended to go to Harrods however upon looking at the menus online, we didn't find it all too enthralling. Upon a quick search on Yelp, I find the Orangery. We were not disappointed.The Orangery is just off Kensington High Street (tube station) on District/Circle. It's easy to get to, and to find the restaurant you have to walk through the lovely park. We were seated immediately, handed menus, and we got the Signature Orange Tea. There is a wide selection of teas. My fellow diners ordered the Tregothnan teas. I ordered a cappuccino, as I'm not too fond of teas. I heard great things about the teas, and my cappuccino was very nice. They were accommodating with my vegetarianism, and only gave me vegetarian sandwiches, which was very nice. The orange-scented scone with clotted cream was to die for and the orange and passion fruit tart is not something you want to miss.While I'm not one for "fine dining" this was a very pleasant experience. The service could have been more attentive, however, the food was excellent. Make sure if you need the restroom that you ask, as it is out around the building, and you need a keycode. Overall, a very nice experience. I would return!

O3TpQLK5pQoQYsGfhEf2eg.text: This place is friggin' lovely.Nursing a warm cup of Tregothnan while staring through the tall windows at the mid-October rainfall and greenery outside was one of 2008's sweetest moments.The most enjoyable aspect of the Orangery, aside from the Orangery itself, is the winding walk through through the lusher-than-life gardens along the way. The restaurant is situated in Kensington Palace Gardens, just a few steps away from Kensington Palace. Afternoon tea begins at three.The tea room is flooded with light, and tiny orange trees adorn each tabletop. The environment here is peaceful, unpretentious and easy. The prices may be higher than one might expect for such a refreshingly informal atmosphere, but for a well-steeped pot of leaves and one of the nicest views in all of London, do rest assured that it's worth the visit.

JgnAlWfdq8ItnC7YX6dk5Q.text: At the Orangery, we sat next to Orange County.The beauty of travel:  You come half a world away and you see the same sorority girls you would see at home. However, we had fun. The service is very attentive and the space clean and bright. A little touristy, though, but ... duh.

u9eVg4HGJCGTF1C-oQRMGA.text: I'll keep it short. Went there with a group of 8 people, that might have been the first mistake. The service was bad they took only half of our order then walked away. The food was OK, the tables were pushed together and wobbly. We received our food then waiter disappeared, we had to get up and find him to pay our bill.

cUF6ZxR44uFGF3An5MOPLg.text: I really really wanted to love this place, but I didn't.  The wait was about 25 minutes on a Sunday and I got there pretty early for tea.  I was alone so they asked if I would sit on one of the couches instead of at a table, which was fine but it ended up being inconvenient to eat on such a low table not to mention the people who were waiting getting up and down on the other couches nearby. I got the Orange afternoon tea.  The food wasn't spectacular, except for the orange scone which was amazing.  The tea was only warm when it arrived but ended up getting cold before my second cup. They don't give you much tea either. I also ordered a rose spumante and the waiter brought me some very different champagne, which I didn't want to make a scene about so I took it but it ended up costing £4 more once I got the bill.  The sandwiches were ok, pastries weren't amazing by any standards.  I saw the waiter once and he never looked at me again, I ended up having to wait around for the bus person to request the bill.  Overall with the wait and poor service and mediocre food I wouldn't recommend it especially for a solo traveler.  I had a better tea experience at National Portrait Gallery cafe.

uVpys0aPvjtFQe7lhLk4Mw.text: If you are going to do tea time in London, you must go to The Orangery!Head over to Kensington Gardens, where The Orangery is found. But beware: The Orangery is only open from 3 to 5 PM. You better get there early or else the wait will be long. The staff also periodically states to the waiters that if it is past the cutoff time, they will NOT be able to serve you!When you step into The Orangery, you enter a beautiful hall that has plenty of light & fresh air. The setting is very elegant. Food is delicious and of course, the tea is great. The food and decor'll fancy your pants! And service is also great, which is a plus, right?

lvksStK9K0V3DzcH9v4WDQ.text: I had the afternoon tea which was delightful. I couldn't help but imagine myself in the 1700s sipping tea and eating crumpets looking out the window at the gardens and palace. The only thing I wasn't satisfied with was the service which lacked in attention, especially with my empty glass of water...this seems to be a common theme in London. Plus they add a service charge, no need to tip.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Looking down from The Orangery steps.

zxM-2a4oZl318EY9xJ4R8A.text: 1 stars only for the venue. 0 star for the food. It was a very disappointed experience for all of us. Every single thing of that high eat set was not worth of wasting space of your stomach. Seriously, it's that bad. London food, you really live on your reputation.

itNEQERQvJ7QKFWw6-PCGw.text: Came here for the afternoon tea.  Loved the tea and the sandwiches were pretty good.  The only thing I didn't like was one of the cake items which I felt was a little too sweet.  Great experience overall and the price was decent.

MAZsGpldmQQkLvXGNO8Z0A.text: Came here for afternoon high tea while visiting London. I would highly recommend this to anyone coming to visit the area. This is right next to kensington palace, a great way to get here is to just walk, come through the gardens behind the palace. The building is beautiful, high ceilings and an airy feel. We got the traditional high tea with a glass of champagne. The service was impeccable and the food was delicious. This was one of my favorite experiences in London. They will let you sit outside if the weather is nice, but it was chilly on our day so we sat inside.

F6PHHsvjWilSlS6hNLM3lw.text: What better way to indulge in a British tradition than to have afternoon tea at the Orangery! It was the PERFECT setting for it, and i was able to kill 2 birds with one stone. I got t to check out kensington gardens, and enjoy afternoon tea on a beautiful london afternoon. Prices are also very reasonable for london standards with the gorgeous view and awesome service. We even got to sit outside on the courtyard patio to admire the view of the garden. We had the signature orange tea for £14.85 per person, which came with an assortment of finger sandwiches, the signature orange scented scone with Cornish clotted cream & strawberry jam. You also get a chocolate éclair and orange & passion fruit tart.  I had the signature/recommended tea - Rooibos breakfast (Orange tea). it was awesome! I absolutely loved the experience & highly recommend it.

8hp4yseOxt9cAYzDItQ5IA.text: So so so lovely. Our friends were so eager for a proper afternoon tea. So happy to take them here in a more casual garden setting, different from the glamorous Ritz High Tea, but equally as charming. Service is impeccable. Sandwiches, biscuits, clotted cream, preserves, champagne and teas...all of it, was simply delicious. Cost is reasonable too.

uROq_M2MOty4vG9b19NXRg.text: High Tea at the Orangery: Can I go back now? Can I go please?????????I miss this place so much, from the beautiful gardens to the madre dene who was so fabulous and the high ceilings  in the all white dining room and classy presentation.We were fortunate to have a bright sunny day in London when we decided to for for High Tea. English Orangery tea £18.95 x 1.7 = ~ $32 per personAn assortment of homemade finger sandwiches-My favorite was the salmon on pumpernickel bread An orange scented scone with Cornish clotted cream and English jam- I LOVE this clotted cream I could have had two or three more if I was not watching my weightA selection of afternoon tea pastriesServed with freshly brewed tea or coffee- Peppermint Tea was my favoriteOnly two minor drawbacks- 1. Things do move slower when you go abroad2. I wish I did not have to go outside and remember a code to use the WC( Wash Closet aka Bathroom)

WQPYX6G65FxO7mzvg1YkYw.text: The Orangery is the perfect spot for the quintessential, fancy afternoon high-tea. Went here on a rarely sunny day, and enjoyed sitting outside with a view of Kensington gardens. High-tea can be expensive, but at the Orangery I feel like you get your bang for your buck (or pound).Beautiful atmosphere, perfect tea, and a lot of delicious sandwiches, scones and pastries.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

INuUokHXDNMUx3fN7LokOQ.text: Yelp said it closes at 5pm on a Sunday so we ran. I really wanted to try afternoon tea in London.  We got there at 5 pm and were seated right away. Score!Everything is white and classy. Love the look. Made things look so elegant and bougie.Tea was so good and refreshing.  Got the earl grey blue flowers.Such cute delicate plates ans cups with amazing design. I felk in love.The food even better! I inhaled the sandwiches and the jam was out of this, world. The best I've had. Made with real strawberry pieces. Dessert was really good too.Overlooks the garden!

nAzRE3d7IGAFl_OGeIA21w.text: Very nice ambience here!Had English Orangery Afternoon Tea that includes Cornish clotted cream- best cream ever! This is definitely the most economic afternoon tea place to go in London. Highly recommended!

4WqxU_Ba5_iSpAcCqfH9lg.text: During my first time in UK I decided to come to The Orangery for proper British afternoon tea. I was hugely disappointed. £29.5 for terrible food. Tea was decent but nothing special.Don't bother if you want to have good food. They don't have it.If you are only looking for a place with nice ambience for your afternoon tea, you should try this place. I am not sure how many pictures you would take to make it worth the £30.Surprisingly Butchart Garden in Victoria, BC has way better food (both in quantity and quality) and tea than this place in UK.

fpRzLl63Bn9asdJwgfO32w.text: Centrally situated in the middle of Kensington. Wonderful teas and wonderful tea sandwiches. Highly recommend the eucalyptus and berry tea. The classic tea set pairing includes 4 tea sandwiches, 2 scones and a variety of fun desserts.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Tea sandwich selection

-hq5gPRBdKJyZ54J8I2kgw.text: An absolute must! Such a pretty venue in beautiful surrounds. A lovely afternoon on a summer day. Everything was good: service, venue, food. Less one star because I felt the cakes in the afternoon tea stand were a little average for the price that said the sandwiches were beautiful. They should also offer more hot water for the tea. But beyond that a trip highlight!

oNrt7G6XNDTHJvosBVQs0g.text: As an avid fan for tea parties, I have to give The Orangery a rounded up 3.5 stars. This being my first time in London, I was giddy about the prospect of having afternoon tea in very place it originated from and that being said, I was definitely looked forward to the Orangery. Located in the Kensington Gardens, the first thing you notice about the Orangery is how impressive it looks right down to the little orange plants on your table. The colonial mansion houses an elegant white restaurant with wide open space to make your experience as leisurely as possible. There aren't too many times you can say you had tea on palace grounds and so a trip to the Orangery is worth that alone. The enviable view and ambiance is part of the reason we had to wait in a queue for about 30 minutes just to be seated but the brisk and pleasant service more than made up for that. We ordered their Signature Orange Tea (about £15 pp) with The Orangery House Tea and the Chocolate/Caramel Tea. Both teas were excellent but the creaminess of the Chocolate/Caramel tea gave it a slight edge.The finger sandwiches including the cucumber and salmon sandwiches were good but not great which is an appropriate description of the scones and pastries. The clotted cream was a nice addition but in terms of food, nothing from the tower really stood out. As for the desserts at the top of the tower, one of them had a neat imprint of one of the royal members of Kensington Palace but aside from that, I was not impressed.  Overall, I thought The Orangery was a lot like Victoria Secret models. Sure,it's nice to look at but there really isn't a lot of substance beyond that. If The Orangery ends up improving on their food, I think it would be a five-star experience especially considering the price is definitely reasonable. That said, The Orangery is a solid but not spectacular choice for afternoon tea in London. Not for tea purists but still a good choice for anyone who likes to enjoy spot of good tea and a dainty lounging experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Photo Credit Camellia C.

ulI6MiX688zil_dbjoNrsw.text: Such a lovely location and setting...but such a disappointment. We arrived at (4:30pm) with a reservation that was happily accepted. However, it became clear that The Orangery was "closing" shortly.  They were not kidding.  The sandwiches and assorted pastries were stale, odd ones placed on our plates as some items had clearly run out.  The real shock, that compels me to write this review...we were unable to get more hot water for our tea.  As I stated earlier, and our server reminded us, they were closing.  We barely squeaked in our tea in under an hour.  Not what one would expect for £104. Go elsewhere..anywhere.

F7XqHrphsH-LPrE4w7Fw_g.text: My husband and I went to the Orangery for afternoon tea.  We picked it because it is a beautiful location, but a better price than some of the other pretty-location teas in London.  It was a lot of fun and very pretty inside and outside in the grounds.  The tea itself was delicious.  I'm deducting 1 star because the pastries were OK, but nothing special.  Definitely go here for the tea and the atmosphere.

x9mEBaLlnar9KqAOVF7VHA.text: I swear I already reviewed this place?!  Oh well... here it goes again.I really enjoyed the atmosphere here.  The venue is lovely and it's a great place to take a break while seeing the sights of Kensington Palace.The tea service was wonderful and I loved the mini kumquat trees on each table.  Such a nice touch.  It wasn't cheap... but nice things never are.  ;-)

TeCcgUdAmdVUKqxyx5biww.text: Great decorGreat scones & teaGreat patioGreat place for sunday brunchIts worth the trip, the line and everything else to go every once in awhile. Perfect for special occasions.

eFzjEI5LhGzbUImY03rYbA.text: Well obviously this is a large tourist attraction.  Nothing scream tourist more than Afternoon Tea at/near Kensington Palace.  We arrived and were seated after taking the tour of the palace and gardens.  It was a gorgeous sunny day in London, and The Orangery was busy.  We went with simple Earl Grey Tea and the little dessert.  The scones and clotted cream are always my favorite, and I must say it tasted better here than anywhere else we had been - but it also could have been because of where we were.Being an American in love with all things England, it was hard to contain my excitement being in this location.  The wait staff were very kind and took the time to tell me little facts about the Royal family, and the location, and the palace itself. I had an amazing time, and it was truly an experience I will treasure.

dnjJJ7cyZTnox5kFduKYqg.text: Unfortunately we could not make it out here for afternoon tea so we tried their breakfast instead. They have outdoor garden seating as well as indoor seating both of which are beautiful. They open the windows so even if you are sitting inside you feel like you can soak in all the beauty of the garden.We tried the Smoked salmon and eggs with a bagel as well as the eggs and cheese with a toasted muffin. Breakfast came with toast, juice, and your choice of tea. The teas we tried were very flavorful and smelled so good! Portions were generous but the food wasn't anything special. Our waiter was very friendly and helpful.

b8fYCLguMXWi-wIQiZkHSA.text: I absolutely loved this place. I came here for afternoon tea. I wanted to find a place that exuded classic English style and this restaurant definitely did that. We ordered 2 of the prixe fixe tea "meals" that came with 1 macaroon, 2 mousse desserts, a raspberry pastry, 4 scones, and mini finger sandwiches. I felt like Marie Antoinette haha. I ordered the mixed berries tea to drink and a lemonade. I can honestly say that that was the best tea I have ever had I regret not buying some to take back home with me. I loved almost everything that came out with the tray. I wasn't that fond of the cucumber sandwiches but that's just my personal preference I don't really like them. I'm sure people who enjoy them would have enjoyed theirs. Everything was superb from the service to the location, and the food. I would love to come back here again. I believe the afternoon tea is a great deal better than at Sketch, which I also went to.

FzcJDRKDwLPfIE45DQDyWA.text: My hubby had made reservations for breakfast for this place. Quite fast and convenient as you can make them online. Beautiful scenery, beautiful sunny day. Glad we took a seat inside as the sun was beating down very hard and we were already very hot inside nearby the window. I ordered a fruit salad with yogurt and a black tea (afternoon in the palace). The yogurt in the fruit salad was not sweet, possibly more like the Greek yogurts which I do not fancy too much. My black tea was great. The plateware at this place is so pretty, definitely have a tea over a beer/cocktail just so you can use the fancy China! My husband got the full english breakfast with eggs sausage bacon and mushroom/tomatoe. It was not very filling for him and nothing too exciting to report from it. They do serve bread when you are seated and it comes with jam and butter. He also ordered an english iced tea which was very delightful and refreshing. I wanted to order the trio of dessert shots with my order but was told from waitor that I had to wait until 12 to order that since its from lunch menu. (Howver breakfast and lunch items were printed on same menu). We finished our food at maybe 15 minutes before 12. I asked the waitor if I could order the dessert but unfortunate they are quite strict on their lunch service time. We waited the 15 minutes to order he dessert. Well worth the wait tho! Vanilla chocolate and lemon dessert shots were all very rich and delicious! If you love sweets, don't miss out on them.

Ar-DV7GpP1Hqp3CDHoKfrQ.text: Cool looking location.  Nice service and food is solid.  Tea is very good.I liked the tea and the sandwiches.  Price is good as afternoon tea in other places in London are much more expensive.I'd definitely recommend it if you are looking for a solid afternoon tea place with a good price.

8n2W3wVZeKTi0rs3Yud5BQ.text: Great place.  Very nice ambience with Harp artist.  High tea is great with excellent china. Almost feel like a princess at the palace.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Love it

nDxT8RKm-QrTJ-_AzaRWxA.text: We made a booking for afternoon tea here based on the Hubs' friend's recommendation. I was really excited to have tea in London, since I only just had my first British style afternoon tea last December at the Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong, and it was amazing there! When we arrived on a Wednesday at 4:30, the place was not even half filled. The scenery outside is lovely though, and we were seated at a table by the window. Too bad the week had been gray and rainiy, otherwise the view would have been splendid. We ordered the regular afternoon tea (with no wine or champagne). The Earl Grey Blue Flowers was pretty good and the Hubs ordered the Darjeeling which was eh. The sandwiches were OK. They looked and tasted like ones you could make at home, especially the ham and mustard one. The scones, plain and raisin, with clotted cream and jam were tasty. The other little cakes and tarts were average to above average. The macaron was disgusting...tasted a bit stiff...they should leave the macaron making up to the French! Even my amateur macarons taste better than theirs (not to boast, but you can ask the Hubs and my co-workers). So maybe my expectations for this place were too high and the weather was not great, but I'd prefer to have some fancier looking and tasting food if I am to go out for tea.

BJPs-4kZhiRWl34p1m-_-w.text: Brilliant!Located next door to Windsor castle, my daughters pretended to be drinking tea with the Princess.  Now I'm not a connoisseur of tea, but we each just about got a different kind of tea, which I tried, and they were all fantastic.  We got a tower of finger sandwiches and desserts along with it and they were great.The best,... chamomile!When all of it was delivered, it appeared we were expecting company, so perhaps everyone getting there own tea and snack plates was a little much.Five stars from a lad without a frame of reference for partaking in afternoon tea, but there was no fault found.Good service, great tea and sandwiches.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. It is the tea then, after all.

2dFEmQzZJ_fyTxWivaS3-g.text: So cute. Such a great experience. High tea in its most adorable form. 26£ for the most basic set, but a yummy assortment of tea sandwiches and cakes, and delicious loose leaf tea options. Beautiful setting and gorgeous tea sets. I already want to go back!

XtV-PmdDeSGnv7B59V7Ppw.text: A must do for London! My first time in England and this is exactly how I envision English Afternoon Tea to be. The walk through Kensington gardens is beautiful. The restaurant itself is stunning with big high windows that overlook the garden. You feel like royalty. The food and tea was also delicious. Pro Tip: As of May 20, 2015, the code to the bathroom is 1515. ;)

uSGDSkYJ-vx2cpEFN-IHMw.text: As many other reviews have mentioned, there are a lot of tourist at this spot (I counted  different languages within earshot- other than English), and I am one of those tourists today.  What impressed me, is that for someone without a booking (ME) they were able to seat me in less than 15 mins at 2:45- 3pm on a Saturday!  Not only that, but they didn't look at me like I was sad or crazy to be dining alone (or to be dressed casually).  That goes a lot way for me, since I am often traveling alone and checking out placed recommended on Yelp.The food itself was delicious.  It was presented well.  It did take a little bit of time to arrive, I wasn't checked in on more than once and they did not offer to refill the water in my tea.  That's probably the only reason to rate them at 4/5 stars.I had the Lady Grey tea and the standard 22.65 GBP Afternoon Tea on the menu.  I noticed other people around me getting different sweets on their tiers, so they must have explored the menu more than me.Overall, for the palatial ambiance (right at Kensington Palace)  and the chance to feel like a royal (even in my jeans and a hoodie), it was totally worth it and i would definitely come back.  Maybe I'll figure out how to get a macaroon next time!NOTE: Bathrooms are outside the from door, on the right side of the building.  You have to ask your server for a code to get in.  They do not have a wait list at the podium - you have to stand in a queue for next seat if you don't have a booking.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea 22.65GBP
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Lady grey tea
Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom

Ha0aAmLqk5Ys2tMscTJXZg.text: The Orangery is located on the grounds of Kensington palace and the grounds are absolutely beautiful. Give yourself some time before or after tea to walk around the gardens.  They're very well maintained and gorgeous. Luckily the day I went with my gf it was nice and sunny so it was a perfect day to walk around the palace grounds. The restaurant itself is a big white room and I didn't think it was anything spectacular.  It does have a sophisticated vibe to it which is what most tea places go for as far as I can tell. The service was decent but not as good as I would expect for the price point.  The server was nice but not attentive as I would have liked.  I needed more hot water for my tea, but it took awhile to get service.  The tea and tea sandwiches were delicious as well as the desserts and scones that came with our afternoon tea. I remember that the scones had a hint of orange to them which was a nice touch.  Overall I enjoyed the experience but for 25 pounds a person I expected a little bit better service.

33HHui0Xaun4CDhbZNnHmg.text: We went to the Orangery on a Sunday afternoon to enjoy high tea. The place was busy but not lined up, and we were promptly taken to a table. Our order was taken quickly, but (and this may be the ravenous hunger talking) we were quite convinced the server had forgotten our food because although the tea came the sandwiches and pastries took forever. No matter, once they arrived the food was good. Although I would be happy to simply have scones with cream/jam (and not pay £24/p), it was a lovely afternoon and a worthwhile place to bring out-of-town guests. After all, who doesn't like to send their Mom a photo from "Kensington Palace" (which isn't entirely untrue)? In any case, it was lovely, less expensive than some alternative High Tea services, and enjoyable; just not somewhere I'd visit except for a special occasion (based largely on price).

iEd5wkTn27kkbZ0AxI35KQ.text: The definition of English afternoon tea. Beautiful location amongst Kensington Gardens. The building itself is remarkable. Enjoyed the fresh scones and the selection of desserts and sandwiches which complimented the tea service. A lovely experience indeed.

rBZm7x75D4pFFqoYvIpHCg.text: Went here for afternoon tea on the patio. Lovely ambience and delicious food, considering its London. The service was excellent and the presentation was playful and made for a pleasant experience. We also didn't feel rushed which is great.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon sunny tea

TZZKDF9hYXomiVNlg7bI5A.text: I first went to The Orangery around 8 years ago and had fond memories of it. I recently just went back as a party of 1. I found being alone meant to the staff, avoid. The staff came by 2x; once to take my order and once to remove my plate. I then went to pay and they tack on 3 pound gratuity automatically. I was not intending to tip because there was no customer service but paid it because I felt embarrassed not to. You are paying purely for ambiance as the afternoon tea is nothing amazing. This is the place to go to for us Americans to have the afternoon tea experience but not pay as much as going to a fancier place. Still very, very overpriced. I also never received clotted cream They just gave me butter. WTF?

zqF5pMP51XZSrwqRJh8SJw.text: Beautiful venue, great service, and lovely afternoon tea spread. My friend and I had the Orangery afternoon tea, which came with two teapots and a tower of small sandwiches, scones, and desserts.  Overall a fantastic experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Orangery - London, United Kingdom. The Orangery standard afternoon tea

kQvcVu2SKFrSps3cuCEdfQ.text: As far as afternoon tea places go, you could certainly do worse than The Orangery. Then again, you could also do better, especially in a city teeming with different options like London. It goes without saying that the venue and atmosphere is second to none - you can't really beat being right next to Kensington Palace! The decor is elegant and refined without feeling too formal or stuffy, and you're surrounded by some of the most perfectly manicured gardens and grounds in the world. And considering the prime location, the £24 price for the basic afternoon tea is a steal. So if you're looking just to check the "I had afternoon tea in England!" experience off your sightseeing to-do list, The Orangery is a fine place to go.What really didn't impress me was the food itself, and the service. While the tea selection is fantastic, the sandwiches were dry and stale, and weren't particularly creative or inspired. The scones were fine but nothing to write home about, and the desserts sadly also tasted old, as if they'd been sitting out for some time. With regards to the service, I'm trying to pinpoint exactly what bugged me the most: the host who, upon seeing my name in the reservation book, showed me to my table without even looking me in the eye and just dumped the menus on the table before stalking away (despite being super lovely and friendly to the pair before me); seeing the manager personally greet every single table BUT ours; or having to flag down waiters every single time we needed our hot water refilled since nobody cared to check in on us in the 2+ hours we were there (despite noticing them checking in on every other table around us). My friend and I were both baffled by how we seemed to be singled out and treated - who knows, maybe we smelled or something - and it made the entire experience quite uncomfortable and unpleasant. What a disappointment.

uMeZKVjegY1F2_PvQlpC-w.text: Yum!Came here twice, on separate holidays to the UK, in order to have proper English tea. Located in the Kensington Gardens, it's a cute little building with grecian/roman architecture (meaning pillars and busts everywhere). The path leading up to the main entrance is surrounded by huge cylindrical shrubs. The interior is v. white and bright and each table has a little orange tree to decorate it.They offer some elaborate teas (that come with champagne, various salads or finger sandwiches, desserts) and you can pick the one most appealing to you. I've had both the darjeeling tea and chamomile tea here. I'm not a fan of the chamomile but the darjeeling was amazing. It was really fragrant and delicious. The teas are accompanied by a cute little dish of sugar cubes (both brown and white) and a little jug of milk.There's a huge selection of pastries and baked goods. I highly recommend getting a scone with clotted cream. They're really fresh and moist and delicious. But I'm sure you can't go wrong with anything you order. Everything I've eaten here has been incredible.Admittedly, it is a bit pricey, but it's worth the experience.

9PQJZH-Q3mVp-8tVJBOjnA.text: Tea and scones in an atmosphere that oozes history... it doesn't get better than this. I could stare at the china on the table all day! An experience that everyone should indulge in!
